question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about how to create meaning in video, from both the perspective of the maker and the viewer. I also learned about the ways that video can be used to convey a political message as well as new ways of thinking about what is meaningful and how to create meaning through my video work.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Throughout this course, I was able to expand my way of thinking on many topics that I once thought I knew everything about. I'm amazed by how Professor Jenny Lion was able to take seemingly widespread concepts and dig deeply into what they meant to our society, so much so that we were able to produce creative video art through examining the contexts of everything we discussed within the course. In Video Art and Politics, I developed a deeper understanding of how moving images can function as both aesthetic expression and political intervention. The course expanded my critical lens as a media maker and viewer. Three specific things I learned are:- The Power of Visual Rhetoric – I gained insight into how visual language, framing, and editing choices can shape political meaning and influence audiences emotionally and intellectually. This helped me reflect more intentionally on my own creative decisions and the messages they convey.- Expanded Definitions of Activism and Art – I learned how artists and filmmakers use nontraditional forms, such as video installations, essay films, and acts of tactical media, as political tools. These works challenged me to rethink the boundaries of what counts as political art and to appreciate the role of experimentation in social critique.- Process as Political Practice – Through the final project and class discussions, I understood how the process of making video art (including collaboration, research, and engagement with communities) can itself be a political act. This insight will continue to shape how I approach media production and storytelling in socially engaged contexts.

I feel like the the first artists using video in the 70s that she showed us were very intriguing and I really enjoyed being exposed to them. Also, Jenny co-ordinated artists to come speak to our class like Wendy Clarke who did The Love Tapes. I found her visit so inspiring that I decided to recreate her work for myself and Jenny kindly connected me with Wendy and formed that connection and gave me lots of advice on how to carry it out respectfully and properly. Jenny said this class is basically about how to change the world - and I really felt like I learnt a lot about activism and how to use my skills in video for things I care about and to help others.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
The overall learning environment of Video Art and Politics was deeply engaging and thoughtfully designed to support both creative exploration and critical thinking. The instructor fostered a space that encouraged experimentation, open dialogue, and personal connection to the material, which was crucial for a course dealing with both art and sociopolitical issues.
One of the most impactful components was the balance between theory and practice—readings and screenings provided historical and conceptual context, while creative assignments allowed us to respond artistically. This dual approach helped me internalize complex ideas through hands-on application. I also appreciated the peer feedback sessions and in-class critiques, which created a collaborative and supportive environment. Hearing from others enriched my perspective and gave me practical suggestions to refine my work.For future years, I’d definitely keep the final project format that allowed us to define our own intervention and work across mediums. It encouraged risk-taking and personal investment, making the course feel both rigorous and meaningful.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course was very helpful in developing technical skills related to filmmaking, editing, film processing, and shooting. Working in the darkroom was a very informative hands-on experience, as was using the Steenbeck manual editing table to splice and cut together films physically. In addition to the Steenbeck editing techniques, we were taught how to use Adobe Lightroom to edit our films digitally. I also got comfortable using the Bolex camera while making films for the class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Please take this course! Madison is a wonderful instructor who will introduce you to the joys and intricacies of analog filmmaking. Instead, grace is given for all students to learn the medium and experiment with their own creative impulses.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course was a great introduction into understanding film on a more technical level! We began with elements of movies like mise-en scene and cinematography and worked our way into more specific details like acting and sound design. This course has fundamentally changed the way I think about movies and made them so much more fun to watch! For example, for the film Punch Drunk Love, before this course, I would have seen it simply as a quirky and confusing romcom. However, after paying attention to things like cinematography, shot composition, the use of a telephoto lens, etc. it took on a whole new meaning and became so much more engaging to watch. Really grateful for this course helping me to put general intuition about a film into clear meaning and technical wording!One of my favorite things we learned about this semester was looking at the evolution and history of film. The course itself follows this progression in the movies we watch. It was really cool to watch clips of earlier work and inspiration for a certain film and then watch the film itself. This gave us a great perspective on where some of these creative and innovative ideas in cinema came from.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the formal elements of film, such as cinematography and mise-en-scene; I also learned to think critically about sound design and the role of directors and actors; and I learned to write formal analyses of films.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned new ways to analyze films, different things to look for when watching films, and a newfound respect for filmmaking as a whole.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The skills to identify and analyze formal elements in films, the history of film as an art and as a technology, and the production process of a film.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

Dr. Cason was really patient with the class and always gave us time to talk and participate in class and through online discussion forums.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

Readings discuss aspects related to video editing - gained skills in reading texts for the purpose of being discussed in class

we learned about Eisenstein's methods of montage, which was also touched on and helped me in a discussion in my remix & sampling class. (I almost wrote a paper about it)I think the projects for this class are really fun and engaging, I like how open ended they are.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

I also appreciated the open-endedness of the second option for project 2 and the assignment for project 3 because it allowed me to make something I was genuinely excited about.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I've learnt a lot in this class, and it had solidified my decision to go into making documentaries professionally.1. I've learnt to be more analytical in my interaction with documentaries as an audience member. I've learnt to not just share initial thoughts but deeply analyse editing techniques, politics, specific frames and angles and how all these come together to tell a compelling story.2. I've learnt to appreciate writing more. We did a lot of writing in this class, from reflections accompanying the different Engage and Mini-Engage assignments and the many free-writes we did in class. It's brought back a lesson I learnt from my old writing teaching: "writing is thinking". I've done a lot of thinking through writing in this class, more than any other class I've taken this semester.3. I've gotten better at intimate interviews, audio documentation and editing and even video documentation and editing. One thing I enjoyed about the class was the Engage Assignments. They made the theory we were learning in class more practical. I'm far from an expert, but this class has provided a strong foundation!

response_text: I would definitely recommend it if you enjoy more hands on work. question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class is what you put into it. If you are genuinely interested in Documentary Studies, you can and will learn a lot and it will be a good foundation, on the other hand, if you are just looking for a seemingly easy class to add to your schedule, this is it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take this with Hyde! She is a great and very lenient professor if you have to miss due to competitions or general sickness. She makes the work and activities super fun!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is not too work intensive but certain days there is often more to prepare so it is good to stay engaged with what is required of you.  As long as you do the work and preparation, you will be all set in the class

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

It's the best form of preparation because you understand the work. There's also a LOT of writing and reflection so be ready to do that.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

Additionally, two other skills that I learned were providing constructive feedback with the understanding that each person has their own spin or creative take on the various assignments and also being able to translate my thoughts into pieces of work (mostly visually) that convey those thoughts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the mechanism behind cameras and how light works to produce images. I learned to use and shoot with a film camera, including the technical and aesthetic aspects of black and white photography. Developed an eye for light, composition and emotional content to drive artistic and documentary storytelling. Learned darkroom techniques such as film processing, printing, burning and dodging and scanning. Discussion of black-and-white photography in seminar setting as well as notable works by photographers in the past and present.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course provided a great basis for learning how to take black and white photos, and specifically film. We learned about the various components of an image such as emotional context and light and how to use a camera (i.e., ISO, shutter speed, and aperture).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned darkroom practices of processing and developing film. I expanded my knowledge of photography and what makes a strong image. I learned how to better shoot black and white.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I definitely developed a much more well rounded set of darkroom skills and it was great to be forced to shoot black and white which was always something that I never did too much of. I've definitely looked at prints in a new light knowing all the things that I could do to it.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned a lot of technical skills in this course, including how to work a film camera, load film, develop film, and print in the darkroom. We also practice talking about our own work and the work of others, both critically and constructively, whether it be famous photographers or our fellow classmates. Additionally, beyond this, in this course, we developed a new way of looking at our surroundings and situations.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Learned the new skill of shooting photos in black and white with film, which I have never done before.
2. Learned how to develop film and print photos in a darkroom.
3. Learned how to work with light, composition, and content to create good photos.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Susie was an excellent teacher, mentor and professional photographer who emphasized not only the technical aspects of film photography but also the aesthetic and emotional component of what made images compelling. She draws from her experiences to teach us the workflow and process of film developing, processing and printing. I enjoyed her anecdotes working for newspapers and Nat Geo as well as her one-on-one mentoring that allowed me to appreciate black-and-white as a medium of art. Susie was always willing to spend time talking about problems we were facing and devoted time for office hours to make herself as available as possible.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely one of the most interesting and exciting classes I've taken at Duke. Film photography and black and white is becoming harder and harder to learn in the digital age so I thought learning the tradition and technique with Susie was the best that could happen. The class, with its emphasis on technical and artistic aspects of photography, complements Susie's other classes, which focus on digital photography in documentary and storytelling settings. Susie wants to develop relationships with students and guide them along the process so although sometimes film can be overwhelming, she made it comforting and enjoyable.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: TAKE THIS CLASS! However, I would definitely recommend having some general background in photography and or darkroom techniques beforehand. This class is definitely demanding but is so interesting.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It's a lot of time commitment. And as someone who had 0 film photography/darkroom experience, I would say that the beginning of the semester where you learn all the techniques/processes will be very hard. But once you practice more and get the hang of it, it's extremely rewarding. I would say if you want to do well in the class, you should be able to spare a good amount of time (could even be 10 hrs/week sometimes).

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a great course if you are beginner or not when it comes to photography or film specifically. Susie is a great professor and invested in our success.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Expect to spend a lot of time in the darkroom. Printing (and processing) can be very tedious. I personally enjoy it, but it definitley takes far more time than I could have expected.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You get out what you put in! It can be time-consuming, but it is so rewarding. Seeing your print turn out after all the effort put into the whole process feels amazing.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Some of the insights I had from taking this course was discussing what could be considered a minor utopia. Throughout the course, we learned about these different utopias and then discussed them in the class, determining if we thought they were a utopia, if we thought they were successful, what the successes/difficulties were, what we didn't like about them, and countless other topics regarding these different utopias. We discussed Crip Camp, Mondragon, Ecovillages, Black Mountain College, and countless other utopias throughout history that helped influence society at the time to reflect how people felt.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned how to edit and create films using premiere pro.
I learned how to assess the positives and negatives of intentional communities using a critical eye.
I learned to recognize the strengths and weaknesses, of both physical texts and virtual mediums such as films, for sharing information.

response_text:
Can divide the class into 2 parts: 
1) First half: mainly had readings from which we would discuss in every class, mainly around the question of whether that minor utopia really was a "minor utopia?" Sometimes, we watched documentaries and critiqued them both in content and cinematography

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Some of the insights I had from taking this course was discussing what could be considered a minor utopia. Throughout the course, we learned about these different utopias and then discussed them in the class, determining if we thought they were a utopia, if we thought they were successful, what the successes/difficulties were, what we didn't like about them, and countless other topics regarding these different utopias. We discussed Crip Camp, Mondragon, Ecovillages, Black Mountain College, and countless other utopias throughout history that helped influence society at the time to reflect how people felt.

The interview series is fantastic. I feel like it sharpened skills that I didn't even know I had, and that would never be acknowledged in other classes. It also feels great to participate in something larger than myself by documenting these people's stories.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned new ways of thinking about the relationship between the press and the government through the readings and activities in this course. I gained knowledge of the history of the watergate scandal, the rise of right wing media, and generally the forces that have brought to bear our current media environment.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) So much subject-specific knowledge, including the norms of journalism, the American press system and its relationship with the government, and, most importantly, what the evolution of the American media ecosystem would mean for both national & global democracy — this prompted a LOT of reflection regarding what my role as a citizen as well as an aspiring journalist is.
2) I learned to think and write like a journalist (Dr. Sullivan especially, being a pro-journalist, imparted so much wisdom to us) — I learned about effective, clear, and engaging information delivery, and how to critically analyze sources for relevancy.
3) A specific 'piece' of knowledge that was super thought-provoking for me was the existence of the press as business entities as well, and how much attracting audiences and generating profits that way influenced the inner workings of the press. Applying that to real life was even more eye-opening — the paywalls blocking access to the New York Times and the Washington Post, for example, are an example of business models that work... But is this at the cost of information access (leading to a more informed populace)? This class really helped me ponder questions like this.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
1) I really liked how discussion-oriented our class was — we were provided with a guiding question each lesson, and it was so interesting exploring various facets of the topic and then delving into further 'branches' of discussion based on interesting observations and points of analysis that my classmates made.
2) Our guest speakers were amazing, and I learned so much from listening to them and asking them questions. Len Downie, who was a key figure in the Washington Post's reporting surrounding the Watergate Scandal, for example, spoke to us, and it was so eye-opening hearing about his first-hand experience — it really brought what we learned to life! (IT'D BE SO COOL TO KEEP BRINGING IN AWESOME GUEST SPEAKERS — EXPERTS IN THE JOURNALISM FIELD — FOR FUTURE STUDENTS & FUTURE CLASSES!)
3) By extension, the syllabus was also super clear — readings for each class (accompanied by our guiding discussion question) were laid out since the beginning of the semester, as were our deadlines. This helped me prepare for our class discussions and helped me contextualize the readings and identify key points.
4) I also liked how the class only happened once a week (but for a long time — 2 hours & 30 minutes) — this meant that the class was more low-stress & manageable, which helped with my learning since I had more time to properly digest the material we'd discuss.
5) Our instructors also created an awesome learning environment — they were super casual, which made me feel a lot more comfortable and confident expressing my views!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I sincerely enjoyed this course and love that it is not a standard Duke course, but an endowed course offered every election season. I think this course not only furthered my knowledge on women in the political process, but helped me to better engage with the Duke and Durham community. I think everyone-- regardless of major, etc-- should take this course!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about different laws, policies, and the gender gape in the electorate process and the transitions of power over the years.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the multifaceted components of politics from different lens. I now understand how media representation is an important influence to how women in politics are perceived. I also learned about different notions of freedom and how it contributes to poltics.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think critically politics, as well as the media surrounding politics. In addition I was able to learn and hone in on my media making skills in terms of both editing, and ethical media making.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained a huge amount of knowledge about US politics and gender, sexuality, and femininity in life and politics. I learnt so much about the election and voting and candidates and how it all works as well as political history. I also improved my media-making skills.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned how to be proficient in media literacy and Premiere pro
I learned about the history of women's involvement in politics, both locally and nationally
I learned how to work in a group and tie comedy into tough subjects

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This was my first class using Premiere Pro. I got an intro course on editing professional-looking videos and collaborating with other editors. Another thing I learned was the difference between campaigns backed by big money and grass roots campaigns. Lastly I learned about the barriers women face to get elected into office and what can be done to encourage more women to run and win.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked that we had an open discussion format. Both professors emphasized respect and open-mindedness, which made me more comfortable to share my thoughts/opinions, even if I felt they were underwhelming. I also enjoyed that we made documentary-style episodes. I felt that I was able to express a creative side to myself that I am not usually able to do through my other Duke courses. Moreover, I like that this was a relatively small class as it allowed us all to bond in a way that would not have been possible with a bigger class, while maintaining fruitful discussion. Finally, arguably my favorite part about this course were the class speakers. I loved engaging with women leaders from various states and sectors of the public. I learned the most from them and their interviews.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked that we had an open discussion format. Both professors emphasized respect and open-mindedness, which made me more comfortable to share my thoughts/opinions, even if I felt they were underwhelming. I also enjoyed that we made documentary-style episodes. I felt that I was able to express a creative side to myself that I am not usually able to do through my other Duke courses. Moreover, I like that this was a relatively small class as it allowed us all to bond in a way that would not have been possible with a bigger class, while maintaining fruitful discussion. Finally, arguably my favorite part about this course were the class speakers. I loved engaging with women leaders from various states and sectors of the public. I learned the most from them and their interviews.

response_text: I was able to learn what photography is made up of and how it is used in our everyday lives. Sociology lives in every aspect of photography.

response_text: I learned about sociological research methods utilizing photography, the ethics of photography, and censorship and content moderation.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how about visual sociology research methods like photo elicitation, I learned about the power that photographs hold to change the world, and I learned about the ethical dilemmas of photography.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned how to conduct a visual research field study by observing a public space and the occupants who used the space (as well as how they used the space).
2. The biggest lesson I learned was that photographs are not the sole truth on their own but require context.
3. I learned how to think like a sociologist when taking and analyzing photographs.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned about photographic research and about examples of past projects that have been conducted. 
I learned about how to think critically about photos and to not just accept them as they are but to consider the photographer-subject relationship, as well as what stories are not being told in the frame of the photo. 
I learned that, oftentimes, photos elicit more questions than answers and it is important to consider what stories are being told, but also to determine which ones are not told.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I loved the structure of the course. I thought that Dr. Hyde did a great job of making sure that the classes were not redundant and that there was variety in the different class structures. I enjoyed how Dr. Hyde mixed in some review days to review the research projects/topics that we had been discussing for the past couple weeks, while making sure that all the student presentations were getting completed in a timely manner. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned about the intersection of climate change and gender theory. 
I explored a new way of being tested through videos/creating documentaries and teamwork.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Technical filmmaking abilities in Premiere pro, the ability to analyze the human relationship with nature through a queer lens, and the ability to analyze difficult texts on the subject of the human relationship with nature.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so much from this class. It was truly transformative—I developed new ways of thinking about climate change through the lens of gender and sexuality, which I'd never thought of before. It opened up my mind! I learned how to make a documentary, which was a feat.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Improved my Premiere Pro skills to create a documentary
2. Reading complex texts to understand how climate and culture are interrelated
3. Interviewing and communicating with community partners and how to tell their stories.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned SO MUCH in this course!! Not only was I able to learn about the theory of feminism, environmental activism, etc, I was also able to apply my knowledge in a meaningful way with a product to show for it. Lauren was very helpful when teaching Premiere Pro. Her office hours were especially helpful for getting to work with her 1:1. I feel confident in my ability to create a film on my own after taking this course.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
how to critically analyze texts
how to create a film!
how to use premiere pro
how to do a group film
list goes on! the profs created an unforgettable experience.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class pushed me to think about gender and ecology in ways I had never considered- how plants communicate, the importance of reciprocity, and practices of collective care. I also learned how to make a film from start to finish: interviewing people, editing footage, adding music—skills I had never explored before. As a computer science major, this was the kind of class I never knew I needed. At Duke, it’s easy to stay in the bubble of econ, finance, and compsci, but courses like this are what the Trinity Arts & Sciences education is really about—broadening your perspective and becoming more well-rounded. As I head into senior year and speak with past seniors, I’m thinking more about what I want to take with me from Duke. For me, that means building deeper relationships and being more present in the community I’ve lived in for four years. This class helped me start doing that.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Filmmaking
- Critical thinking about text, filmmaking, artistry, lived experiences
- Connecting ideas through multiple medium

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: What did we not learn? We engaged with texts from feminist theory to science fiction about aliens, we presented and discussed weekly, we worked together on the Duke Campus Farm, we made sauerkraut together, we worked closely and intensively in small groups and with community partners and activists to make 10 minute documentary films. We learned how to use Premiere Pro, how to connect with community members unaffiliated with Duke who we would otherwise never have met, and how to mesh all of the experiences from this class into one hugely fulfilling project.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: 1) I learned video editing skills in Premiere Pro. 2) I learned how to interview people and how to guide them to answer questions that are part of a broader theme. 3) I improved my teamwork skills and to play a supportive role when working with others.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Through this course, I developed (and fine-tuned) filmmaking, editing, and software skills by curating student-led film projects in collaboration with community partners in the Triangle area. I gained insights from course texts that engaged with queer and feminist theory, developing new ways of thinking about the current climate crisis, of being in relation with one another, and how (both tangibly and theoretically) to live and embody these concepts (not just read, think, and write about them). I learned how to work collaboratively on a long-term creative project in such a way that builds on our individual and collective strengths. I explored new elements of our relationship to our environment, from our biological traits to the science behind our gut-brain connection.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Of all of the classes I took this semester, this class provided me one of the most enriching and insightful experiences. From our weekly assigned readings and discussion posts, I learned how to critically read and analyze complex texts related to ecology and feminist studies. From our visits to the Duke Campus Farm, I learned about the farm's history and also engaged with specific practices including mulching, weeding, and broad-forking. Throughout the process of completing our final project, I learned how to make a short documentary and all of the moving parts that such an initiative requires (eg. recording interviews, writing narration, drafting a storyboard, editing).

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: These instructors were two of the best I have had at Duke and were really detrimental to my learning and progression in the course. They facilitated my learning by always being available to speak both formally and informally. For example, I spent three hours in Lauren's office with my final film and she willingly helped me make it a product I was proud of.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructors were amazing at facilitating in class discussion and creating an environment where I felt safe to share my ideas even when I was not fully confident in my abilities in the area. In the future, I would most definitely keep the seminar style of this class as I felt that was most important to my learning.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I thought the texts built on each other in a really constructive way, which was great for my learning. I enjoyed the discussion posts because I could learn from my fellow students. I also really enjoyed hearing about Lauren's work as someone who is working in the documentary film world. She's doing some really amazing work. The Premiere Pro workshops were also wonderful, as well as the short practice videos (they were also just really fun). Also, definitely keep the farm work day! That was so great.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: There were lots of discussions, presentations and technical workshops that allowed us all to engage with the material and each others' ideas well.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed the timing of the class, meeting one time per week. The discussion questions helped me organize my thoughts before coming to class. I also really enjoyed being able to create videos on my own before contributing to a larger group project. I think a lot of this class relied on individuals doing the initial work and then collaborating in order to further comprehension.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: they opened up office hours nearly every hour of the day. they allowed us to be ourselves to the fullest, something not always respected at Duke. they created a safe space to speak about issues that feel burdensome to speak about at Duke. eternally grateful for how they create in-class time to work on our projects and make sure to facilitate our own working time outside of class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructors were absolutely essential to my learning experience. They went above and beyond—always available for guidance, support, and feedback. I spent countless hours in Lauren’s office with my roommate and teammate as she helped us shape our film, offering both technical help and insight. Their dedication created a learning environment where we felt supported every step of the way.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructors were just incredible. As a junior at Duke, this is easily the most profound course I have taken. The instructors were attentive, caring, and knowledgeable. Saskia helped guide and provoke discussions with thoughtful questions and a diverse array of activities to simulate our thinking. Lauren had so much insight to share and I could not imagine someone more supportive to learn filmmaking for the first time from. They were both receptive and open to helping students however possible and whenever necessary. I always felt excited going to class because we were doing something new and talking about something meaningful, which expanded my broader knowledge of climate, justice, and their intersection. We participated in a lot of hands-on activities, like visiting the Duke Campus Farm and making sauerkraut, that helped me grasp texts in a fun and meaningful way. I loved this experiential aspect as well as the final project, which was incredibly rewarding and insightful and allowed me to truly connect with the Durham community for the first time. I was also pushed outside of my comfort

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The co-teaching style of this class was perfect for the structure and material. Professor Cornes engages more directly with the readings, while Professor Henschel handles the film end of things. The activities like the trip to the farm and sauerkraut workshop were not only bonding and fun but also relevant to the material and intellectually engaging. The film was the biggest part of the class, and it was one of the most challenging but also most fulfilling projects I've ever done.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This class was structured very well. It was a great balance of experiential learning at the Duke Campus Farm, creative exploration while filmmaking, and intellectual stimulation through course readings. I would definitely keep the visits to the Duke Campus Farm and filmmaking lessons for future classes. Through these unique experiences, and considering that people from different majors enroll in the class, they all have the opportunity to try something new and maybe find a new passion, like I did for filmmaking.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Each day of class, Saskia and Lauren began with a prompt, encouraging us to reflect on something new or exciting or even pick up on a thread or concept from the previous week. What seemed like such a small moment at the beginning of each class ended up bringing us closer together, celebrating our individual wins as a class and offering glimpses of joy when weeks were particularly difficult. Saskia and Lauren united us, creating an environment centered around care, community, and curiosity, creating space for intellectual growth and even humility, recognizing that we do not always have the answers. Lauren and Saskia were always available to field questions about our film, about the content of the course that we found particularly challenging, fascinating, or frustrating. Lauren offered a space to develop new film editing skills using Premiere Pro, providing countless opportunities to meet during office hours to learn new workarounds and shortcuts to enhance the power of our project.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I appreciated being able to read and discuss a variety of readings throughout the semester, and I think that the weekly required discussion posts encouraged me to engage with each text more thoughtfully. I also enjoyed creating one-minute short videos regarding these readings and class concepts because they helped me develop my skills prior to working on the final project. My favorite component of the class was, likewise, the process of creating our short documentary. It was an incredibly memorable and transformative learning experience to be able to connect with community members and try to communicate a story in a new way.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Really engaging course.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This course challenge me to produce in a new medium (a documentary) that was deeply rewarding in its production as I learned more about our climare, the durham community, and the larger field of gender and sexuality studies. I often take very quantitative-focused courses and this was a promising deviation from that.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The way Saskia and Lauren weaved through texts, films, class discussions, and the filmmaking component was masterful. This is an unforgettable class.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: We got to read and watch diverse kinds of materials with topics I have never thought about.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The diversity in topics covered in this class made it stimulating. Everyone was able to present on a topic, and. nobody's presentations were even remotely similar. Also, being able to discuss for 2.5 hours was very helpful when wanting to dive into the topics.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It was a truly stimulating experience—we explored a wide range of topics, read thought-provoking texts, watched powerful films, conducted interviews, and even created our own. The variety of learning methods made the course both dynamic and impactful.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Digesting different forms of media, getting out into the community, collaborating with and highlighting narratives from community partners, engaging in a full filmmaking process, critically analyzing text, drawing connections between different authors, styles, and ideas, hands-on activities directed by students and the professors, presenting our own takeaways from a fim/reading. Everything about this course was stimulating for me personally and led to a very high level of engagement that was refreshing to have from a Duke course.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class was stimulating because we were doing something different every week. One week, we would go to the Duke Campus Farm and participate in the Community Work Days. Another week, we would have a filmmaking workshop in the Center for Documentary Studies and learn new technical skills for editing. I also felt like our class because a family by the end of the semester. I looked forward to coming to class to feel like a part of my class community.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I found this course's multimedia approach to be highly intellectually stimulating. It allowed us to cut through and across academic houses, from intellectual “authorities” on the Anthropocene to visionary Indigenous thinkers such as Robin Kimmerer and Tommy Pico's powerful poetics.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Lauren and Saskia's teaching made this class thoroughly stimulating. Whether it was reading our discussion posts each week, asking thought-provoking questions to encourage class conversation, or presenting class concepts through engaging presentations, Saskia helped cultivate an environment where students were excited and interested in what we were learning. Lauren, likewise, brought her invaluable technical expertise when supporting our learning as beginner filmmakers. I greatly valued her feedback on our one-minute videos and full-length documentary, and our final project benefitted immensely from her insight. My favorite aspect of this class was the ability to visit and directly engage with the Duke Campus Farm community. I also appreciate our having had the special opportunity to speak with filmmakers who visited our class and provided additional feedback on our documentaries.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it! New way of learning for me through documentary and video work and team based projects.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is a course that will challenge you to think in new ways and consider ideas through a new lens. There is an important intersectionality between these ideas that are often not considered.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It was an amazing class where we got to not only engage deeply with the class materials and theory, but creating a film out of it was very rewarding at the end. It was so cool to be able to talk to community members and be able to tell their stories in a not as traditional way you would see in other classes in universities.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Invest in the course early on and think about how the different topics connect is very valuable.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: this class is a unique opportunity that i never had as a senior. it was my favorite class at Duke! the professors are more than professors, and want to be there to support us in every realm of life.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take this class - I came in knowing nothing about the topics and walked away having learned so much. It was incredibly rewarding to learn how to make a film and to understand how to communicate ideas in a way that’s powerful and resonant. Plus, you’ll automatically be engaged with the local community, which is a great opportunity for students who struggle to find time to connect beyond campus.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Come in with an open mind. Be willing to learn from others and share your own ideas. Think deeply and embrace all parts of the filmmaking process. Enjoy it!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it, but be prepared to give it your all! Be prepared for technical difficulties, but you will overcome them!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would say that you'll be a different person by the end of the semester. By taking this class, you will learn how to be compassionate toward others and how to be an active member of the community. You will realize that making a difference even in just your immediate community is meaningful and impacts the lives of others. I would also say that taking this class will make you see the world in a different way. For me, it made me realize that films are not just for entertainment; they can play an activist role and be a form of resistance.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This was truly the most powerful, rewarding, collaborative, and intellectually challenging course I have taken in my four years at Duke. I recommend this course to those interested in gender studies, environmental justice, queer theory, farming, especially if these are new or unfamiliar concepts to you.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I could not recommend this class enough to any student who is interested in the climate, ecology, gender theory, community-engaged learning, or documentary filmmaking. Whether a student has a background in these subjects or an interest they want to explore, this class offers such a special opportunity to engage with any or all of these areas. Taking this class taught me how to consider gender theory and climate change - two topics that I had not previously assumed to be connected - in relation to each other. It was unforgettable to be able to learn by physically being at the Duke Campus Farm and building relationships with the people working there. This class showed me what it can look like to try something new, become more aware of my own positionality as a student, and engage with my environment (including the land and its people) more conscientiously.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned about the intersection of climate change and gender theory. 
I explored a new way of being tested through videos/creating documentaries and teamwork. 
I developed presentation skills through our class presentations.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Technical filmmaking abilities in Premiere pro, the ability to analyze the human relationship with nature through a queer lens, and the ability to analyze difficult texts on the subject of the human relationship with nature.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so much from this class. It was truly transformative—I developed new ways of thinking about climate change through the lens of gender and sexuality, which I'd never thought of before. It opened up my mind! I learned how to make a documentary, which was a feat.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Improved my Premiere Pro skills to create a documentary
2. Reading complex texts to understand how climate and culture are interrelated
3. Interviewing and communicating with community partners and how to tell their stories.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned SO MUCH in this course!! Not only was I able to learn about the theory of feminism, environmental activism, etc, I was also able to apply my knowledge in a meaningful way with a product to show for it. Lauren was very helpful when teaching Premiere Pro. Her office hours were especially helpful for getting to work with her 1:1. I feel confident in my ability to create a film on my own after taking this course.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
how to critically analyze texts
how to create a film!
how to use premiere pro
how to do a group film
list goes on! the profs created an unforgettable experience.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class pushed me to think about gender and ecology in ways I had never considered- how plants communicate, the importance of reciprocity, and practices of collective care. I also learned how to make a film from start to finish: interviewing people, editing footage, adding music—skills I had never explored before. As a computer science major, this was the kind of class I never knew I needed. At Duke, it’s easy to stay in the bubble of econ, finance, and compsci, but courses like this are what the Trinity Arts & Sciences education is really about—broadening your perspective and becoming more well-rounded. As I head into senior year and speak with past seniors, I’m thinking more about what I want to take with me from Duke. For me, that means building deeper relationships and being more present in the community I’ve lived in for four years. This class helped me start doing that.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Filmmaking
- Critical thinking about text, filmmaking, artistry, lived experiences
- Connecting ideas through multiple medium

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: What did we not learn? We engaged with texts from feminist theory to science fiction about aliens, we presented and discussed weekly, we worked together on the Duke Campus Farm, we made sauerkraut together, we worked closely and intensively in small groups and with community partners and activists to make 10 minute documentary films. We learned how to use Premiere Pro, how to connect with community members unaffiliated with Duke who we would otherwise never have met, and how to mesh all of the experiences from this class into one hugely fulfilling project.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: 1) I learned video editing skills in Premiere Pro. 2) I learned how to interview people and how to guide them to answer questions that are part of a broader theme. 3) I improved my teamwork skills and to play a supportive role when working with others.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Through this course, I developed (and fine-tuned) filmmaking, editing, and software skills by curating student-led film projects in collaboration with community partners in the Triangle area. I gained insights from course texts that engaged with queer and feminist theory, developing new ways of thinking about the current climate crisis, of being in relation with one another, and how (both tangibly and theoretically) to live and embody these concepts (not just read, think, and write about them). I learned how to work collaboratively on a long-term creative project in such a way that builds on our individual and collective strengths. I explored new elements of our relationship to our environment, from our biological traits to the science behind our gut-brain connection.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Of all of the classes I took this semester, this class provided me one of the most enriching and insightful experiences. From our weekly assigned readings and discussion posts, I learned how to critically read and analyze complex texts related to ecology and feminist studies. From our visits to the Duke Campus Farm, I learned about the farm's history and also engaged with specific practices including mulching, weeding, and broad-forking. Throughout the process of completing our final project, I learned how to make a short documentary and all of the moving parts that such an initiative requires (eg. recording interviews, writing narration, drafting a storyboard, editing).

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: These instructors were two of the best I have had at Duke and were really detrimental to my learning and progression in the course. They facilitated my learning by always being available to speak both formally and informally. For example, I spent three hours in Lauren's office with my final film and she willingly helped me make it a product I was proud of.
