It was so cool to be able to talk to community members and be able to tell their stories in a not as traditional way you would see in other classes in universities.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Invest in the course early on and think about how the different topics connect is very valuable.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: this class is a unique opportunity that i never had as a senior. it was my favorite class at Duke! the professors are more than professors, and want to be there to support us in every realm of life.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take this class - I came in knowing nothing about the topics and walked away having learned so much. It was incredibly rewarding to learn how to make a film and to understand how to communicate ideas in a way that’s powerful and resonant. Plus, you’ll automatically be engaged with the local community, which is a great opportunity for students who struggle to find time to connect beyond campus.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Come in with an open mind. Be willing to learn from others and share your own ideas. Think deeply and embrace all parts of the filmmaking process. Enjoy it!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it, but be prepared to give it your all! Be prepared for technical difficulties, but you will overcome them!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would say that you'll be a different person by the end of the semester. By taking this class, you will learn how to be compassionate toward others and how to be an active member of the community. You will realize that making a difference even in just your immediate community is meaningful and impacts the lives of others. I would also say that taking this class will make you see the world in a different way. For me, it made me realize that films are not just for entertainment; they can play an activist role and be a form of resistance.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This was truly the most powerful, rewarding, collaborative, and intellectually challenging course I have taken in my four years at Duke. I recommend this course to those interested in gender studies, environmental justice, queer theory, farming, especially if these are new or unfamiliar concepts to you.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I could not recommend this class enough to any student who is interested in the climate, ecology, gender theory, community-engaged learning, or documentary filmmaking. Whether a student has a background in these subjects or an interest they want to explore, this class offers such a special opportunity to engage with any or all of these areas. Taking this class taught me how to consider gender theory and climate change - two topics that I had not previously assumed to be connected - in relation to each other. It was unforgettable to be able to learn by physically being at the Duke Campus Farm and building relationships with the people working there. This class showed me what it can look like to try something new, become more aware of my own positionality as a student, and engage with my environment (including the land and its people) more conscientiously.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course was a great introduction into understanding film on a more technical level! We began with elements of movies like mise-en scene and cinematography and worked our way into more specific details like acting and sound design. This course has fundamentally changed the way I think about movies and made them so much more fun to watch! For example, for the film Punch Drunk Love, before this course, I would have seen it simply as a quirky and confusing romcom. However, after paying attention to things like cinematography, shot composition, the use of a telephoto lens, etc. it took on a whole new meaning and became so much more engaging to watch. Really grateful for this course helping me to put general intuition about a film into clear meaning and technical wording!One of my favorite things we learned about this semester was looking at the evolution and history of film. The course itself follows this progression in the movies we watch. It was really cool to watch clips of earlier work and inspiration for a certain film and then watch the film itself. This gave us a great perspective on where some of these creative and innovative ideas in cinema came from.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the formal elements of film, such as cinematography and mise-en-scene; I also learned to think critically about sound design and the role of directors and actors; and I learned to write formal analyses of films.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned new ways to analyze films, different things to look for when watching films, and a newfound respect for filmmaking as a whole.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The skills to identify and analyze formal elements in films, the history of film as an art and as a technology, and the production process of a film.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Cason is an extremely knowledgable professor who clearly cares a lot about his students! I appreciated the thoughtful slides before the films detailing the aspects of film we were considering that class which then directly connected to the film we were watching. Dr. Cason was really patient with the class and always gave us time to talk and participate in class and through online discussion forums.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I thought the rubrics for the assignments were very clear. For the first paper, the instructor set up 15-minute meetings to address any questions or look over any current draft we had written. He was also very understanding if we were busy in other classes and granted extensions for major assignments if we needed more time to construct a quality response.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The professor did a great job in incorporating discussions and weekly reflection posts with the theme of the week and the films screened in class that week. This is great because we can discuss films together and draw inspiration from other students' commentary and practice using the language of formal analysis in the study of films.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Many of the movies we watched were ones I wouldn't necessarily go for on my own. However, I really enjoyed all of them! This aspect took me out of my comfort zone. Some of the films required more thought and engagement, and the pre-screening content helped students prepare and be engaged.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The papers and midterm encouraged us to think critically about formal elements and other components of films, which was intellectually stimulating. In addition, I appreciated how we were able to choose our own film to analyze for the first paper because that eased my approach to practicing formal analyses.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class was stimulating, intellectually challenging, and rewarding because learning to analyze films is like learning to speak a new language. We had to use such language in our papers and exams where we had to analyze the formal choices of the films. It was overall a great learning experience.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I think every student should take this class (or one similar)! Film and video is becoming this generations main source of content, and this course will take you from a passive consumer to analyzing and better understanding cinema. It's super interesting, the films are diverse and engaging!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Please take this course to fulfill the ALP Trinity requirement! I genuinely looked forward to attending this class each week because it was a great break from traditional lecture- or seminar-based classes in that you get to watch movies each class and then engage in some discussion afterward that encourages you to apply your knowledge of film techniques or theories to what you watched during that class session.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you are interested in films--either you are a movie fan or someone who is pursuing a degree in film studies--I definitely recommend taking this class with Dr. Cason. Professor Cason is super accessible and helpful, and this class provides you with a taste of film analysis and film theory in a relatively low-stake environment where a diverse range of opinions and creativity collides. It will be a wonderful choice if you are seeking to get credits for humanities/art classes.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This was an amazing class for introducing students to film studies. As someone who had never taken a film class before, this gave me the necessary skills to analyze a film, discuss it, and learn how to write about film in a sophisticate and formal way. I highly recommend this class to anyone who has even the slightest bit of interest!

response_text: We learned the basics of film studies: genres, cinematography, sound design, narratives, etc. The class started with lectures about the topic covered by required readings. Then, we watched films together in class and had a small discussion at the ends.

response_text: How to analyze film form, the value of auteur, and writing reflectively on a film's interpretation.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I love how engaged Dr. Coates is with the material. His method of teaching really forces the material to stick in students' heads. I loved when he drank out of his mug after dirtying it with his shoe. It gives me chills to this day.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The wide variety of topics within the study of religion that we discussed made the course more interesting. Coming in, I was naively expecting a focus on Christianity, but the course looks at all kinds of religious practices and religions.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

response_text: This class was stimulating because of the fresh perspective it provided on familiar films. However, in addition to the unclear expectations on assignments, many of the readings were extremely verbose and obfuscated the essential meaning of what they were trying to say--I would have liked some explanation of what each of the sources was trying to get across.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class was an amazing introduction to religion in general and the links drawn between popular films and different religions throughout the world. It really will give you a new perspective, not only when looking at movies, but when analyzing any piece of literature.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Dr.Coates rocks! Lectures are very engaging and the readings are very manageable. Film screenings are a treat, and class discussions are never dull.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be prepared to be involved in the course, because passive participation will lead you to being left in the dust.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is intellectually stimulating and very interesting. Movies are fun and interesting to watch. It makes you really think and participating in the in-class discussions will help you walk away with more information. What you get out of the class is what you put in.

response_text: I enjoyed the readings and movies and the class discussions we had about them. The movie screenings were really useful to engage with the material and bounce off of other peoples' ideas. The mini-reviews are interesting assignments to apply the knowledge gained over each unit.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked Coates' teaching style - some film clips, some discussion, some lecture. I really liked how we had four in-class film screening days - we watched "The Conjuring," "Star Wars," "God's Not Dead," and "Kumaré." I liked our "mini review" assignments, where you basically produce a 7-minute film review using a class reading from that specific unit and you have to argue why it should be considered religious. The movies and clips we'd watch in class were more obviously religious, so this was a chance for us to get creative and find something that seems secular and apply it to our learnings.

2- I learned to find inspiration in other peoples' works. Throughout the course, I watched the works of my classmates, which have been amazing, and as I learned more about their experiences, I learned to reinterpret my own and express them through film.
3- Collaboration is necessary. Dance film is the kind of hybrid work that requires working across different fields, therefore bridging them and that connection can only be me through other people.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learnt new ways of thinking about the idea of a 'documentary'. This class exposed me to very niche and different styles of video and documentary. I learnt some new editing techniques using Adobe Premiere Pro as well as new things about cameras and how to work in manual mode. I feel like this course was not a typical film course - it prompted me to think differently and be exposed to different kinds of video art.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about how to create meaning in video, from both the perspective of the maker and the viewer. I also learned about the ways that video can be used to convey a political message as well as new ways of thinking about what is meaningful and how to create meaning through my video work.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Throughout this course, I was able to expand my way of thinking on many topics that I once thought I knew everything about. I'm amazed by how Professor Jenny Lion was able to take seemingly widespread concepts and dig deeply into what they meant to our society, so much so that we were able to produce creative video art through examining the contexts of everything we discussed within the course. In Video Art and Politics, I developed a deeper understanding of how moving images can function as both aesthetic expression and political intervention. The course expanded my critical lens as a media maker and viewer. Three specific things I learned are:- The Power of Visual Rhetoric – I gained insight into how visual language, framing, and editing choices can shape political meaning and influence audiences emotionally and intellectually. This helped me reflect more intentionally on my own creative decisions and the messages they convey.- Expanded Definitions of Activism and Art – I learned how artists and filmmakers use nontraditional forms, such as video installations, essay films, and acts of tactical media, as political tools. These works challenged me to rethink the boundaries of what counts as political art and to appreciate the role of experimentation in social critique.- Process as Political Practice – Through the final project and class discussions, I understood how the process of making video art (including collaboration, research, and engagement with communities) can itself be a political act. This insight will continue to shape how I approach media production and storytelling in socially engaged contexts.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
The overall learning environment of Video Art and Politics was deeply engaging and thoughtfully designed to support both creative exploration and critical thinking. The instructor fostered a space that encouraged experimentation, open dialogue, and personal connection to the material, which was crucial for a course dealing with both art and sociopolitical issues.
One of the most impactful components was the balance between theory and practice—readings and screenings provided historical and conceptual context, while creative assignments allowed us to respond artistically. This dual approach helped me internalize complex ideas through hands-on application. I also appreciated the peer feedback sessions and in-class critiques, which created a collaborative and supportive environment. Hearing from others enriched my perspective and gave me practical suggestions to refine my work.For future years, I’d definitely keep the final project format that allowed us to define our own intervention and work across mediums. It encouraged risk-taking and personal investment, making the course feel both rigorous and meaningful.

response_text: The only thing that I learned in this course, was to never take a class taught by Tim Tyson again. While Professor Williams was lovely and kind. Tim Tyson was arrogant, condescending, and the exact opposite of what I would expect to see in a member of Duke Faculty. To start, he went on an anti semetic rant in class where he said "no one talks about jew power, but they quietly have power through the banking industry". While I am not jewish, to see this behavior from a member of such a prestigious university was disgusting. One of my friends in the class is Jewish, and the fact that he had to sit and listen to professor Tysons' ridiculous comments were insane. I also feel very afraid to take action regarding these comments, because Tyson has been extremely vindictive throughout the semester. For example, the majority of the class got an extremely poor grade on the midterm. Instead of trying to help students improve, he said "if I had taken the test I would have gotten a 100". I was one of the fortunate few students who got a B (most got a C, D, or F) however he still refused to respond to an email I sent asking him for help in the class. I hope that there is some training given to Tyson in the future to fix his anti semetic and belittling behavior.

course: DOCST-326-01 : THE SOUTH IN BLACK AND WHITE.DOCST-326-01.AAAS-230-01.HISTORY-358-01.RIGHTS-326-01.
question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The syllabus underwent changes once the class began, which is generally not permitted. Initially, a take-home midterm was listed in the syllabus, but about a week before the midterm, it was abruptly changed to an in-class midterm without proper notice or consent from the students. By the time grades were returned for that midterm, the deadline to take the class on a satisfactory/unsatisfactory basis or withdraw had already passed. Additional assignments were introduced after this deadline, and the final exam was no longer the sole examination, contrary to what was stated in the syllabus. The grading is stringent, with all assessments being written responses, and any deviation from the professor's expected answers can result in low or even zero scores, immediately impacting overall grades. Throughout the course, students do not have access to a visible grade book or platform like Canvas, making it challenging to track their progress as the syllabus and assignments continue to change unexpectedly. To perform well, memorizing terms from the assigned readings is essential, as outside information is often dismissed, and only definitions from the specified texts are accepted for full credit.

response_text: This course taught me, more than any JAM course I've taken at Duke, how to be a great journalist. It taught me powerful interviewing skills, provided me with ethical knowledge about the profession, and gave me tools to approach the writing process when a piece is feature length.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think Bronwen did an incredible job of balancing writing with reading in this course. Each week we were assigned several long-form pieces to read around a specific topic which we could discuss in class and learn how to emulate in our own work. She gave us all the opportunity to discuss with the class what we found the most gripping and why. She pushed us to be critical of what we've read and identify the key writing tools used to move the story forward.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Bronwen was literally incredible. No other word but that. She fostered an environment of being honest with our thoughts and healthy discourse. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

She has a deep reverence for the power of journalism, a reverence that she passes on and builds in each of her students. The class is perfect as is, and Bronwen was fantastic.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to be a better journalist who can structure, write and edit longer articles. I also learned how to be a valuable member of a team, constantly providing my peers with feedback for their articles. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: interviewing, writing, scene building, communication, collaboration, editing, etc

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
This class taught me a lot about building scenes, particularly for journalism writing (but also writing in general). I learned a lot of practical advice that helped me in other courses that involved writing.
I became an avid reader of long-form journalism because of this course; it introduced me to websites like Sunday Long Read and Longform.org, and I'm very grateful for that.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to interview respectfully, how to approach a monumental writing task in small pieces, how to empathize with stories different from our own

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I improved my writing, research skills, and interview techniques. I also improved in overall communication.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. We learned how to write a scene. We learned about the technical aspects including information to include but also artistic aspects about how to best recreate a point in time. 
2. We learned about different structures of long form journalism. We learned how to weave information between scenes to create a full picture of an issue and its underlying events. 
3. We read many long form articles and discusses how the authors' choices contributed to the emotional impact, clarity, and flow.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: My writing was improved, specifically my scene writing and my comfort using the first-person when necessary. I learned a whole lot about how to find details where they may not be obvious, how to look for specificities and how to represent them well in journalistic writing. Most importantly, I learned how to apply radical empathy to the job of journalist.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class was a stellar deep dive into skills I thought I had already acquired. This is a class for beginner writers of many kinds, but especially the writer who has never dealt with creative ways of expressing ideas. I learned so much about how to write beautifully, how to tell someone's story in a way that does them justice, and how to phrase ideas in unique ways. On top of beautiful writing skills, I learned a lot about how to critique and take criticism. Barry effectively sets an example for how to break down works, both iconic and beginner pieces, and understand their structure, their qualities, and potential improvements. Additionally, we learned how to investigate. I believe this is applicative to many classes. Research is a term broadly used in descriptions for investigative pieces, but Barry emphasizes that research comes in many forms. I loved this class and I can confidently say I have learned the most in this once-a-week seminar compared to any other class at Duke.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this class, I really did learn how to write a long form article. We read new stories and analyzed them every week and were given the opportunity to craft our own over the semester. I was introduced to new writers, ways of writing, and ideas.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: he did a great job including checks and balances all throughout the semester so that we had feedback on our writing throughout the entire process.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: He relied a lot on peer feedback sessions and divided the class into small groups. We had the same workshop group for the entire semester, and it really helped us develop lasting relationships and approach peer editing in a more intimate and comprehensive way.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Barry Yeoman was the best professor I've ever had Duke. Our class and I absolutely adored him in every way. He instilled confidence in all of us. He believed in us. He granted us tips and tricks while also giving us the time to build. I have never learned more in a class and have been more eager to apply my learnings to my future. Barry grew a community of friendship in this class and I looked forward to it every week.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Yeoman has been one of my favorite teachers I have had so far at Duke. He is so personable and approachable, and he makes every single class engaging (it doesn't feel 2.5 hours long). I like the way the semester is structured in three parts.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Barry was phenomenal. He came with a plan, mapping out class to the minute, but it never felt constricted. It actually allowed for some breathing and flexibility. His comments always allowed our class to bounce off one another and make it truly feel like a round table seminar of sorts. By splitting up the gigantic task of a long-form piece into all of his components, it truly revealed his paramount writing skills and, more importantly, his masterful teaching.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Yeoman provided very helpful and very thorough feedback on all of our assignments. He gave us freedom in our article topic and supported each one of us. He cares for all his students.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Yeoman rocks. He cares so much about every piece of writing that I turned in, taking the time to give everything feedback and noting where it might be relevant to bring up in class. I'd have him keep everything he does.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: He really made the class an even playing field. Instead of the wise knowledge giver and unknowing serfs, Barry met us in the middle. He validated our skills and individually directed us on improvements. Seminars are a wonderful structure that allow for this.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Writing a long form article for the first time is daunting, but the structure of this class and Barry Yeoman's constant encouragement and suggestions made it enjoyable. Over the course of the semester, we wrote one major long form article, but it was split up in parts. I really enjoyed this way of writing. We also had workshop groups that facilitated conversation and helped with edits. All of the feedback I got was so helpful and I feel as though I am a better writer after this semester.

response_text: It doesn't matter if you want to pursue journalism or not, this class will improve your writing and open your eyes to ongoing world issues. It challenges you to connect deeply with people and advocate for those who cannot advocate for themselves.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Absolutely take this course if Barry Yeoman is teaching. He is an exceptional professor, journalist, and person. You don't have to be a great writer to love or do well. I didn't consider myself a writer before, but now I know that I can create a story.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Analyzing longform journalism pieces critically 
2. How to conduct interviews professionally and productively 
3. How to give constructive editing feedback to others

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Interview skills
- Scene building
- How to become a better journalist

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The most obvious skill you learn in this course is how to *do* longform journalism — how to write it, how to read it, how to understand it. In doing that, you learn how to ask good questions and follow-up with better ones, how to build source networks and get people to trust you. I came in with an extensive journalism background, having written longform before, and I learned more from this class than I have any other journalism class at Duke. Distilling it into a few things is a disservice to Barry.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to interview, write, and edit an article for long form journalism. I had no prior experience with long form writing before this, and I feel very comfortable with it now.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned how to write vivid and descriptive scenes, informative explainers, and how to structure one long-form journalism piece. I learned about the importance of writing with vivid detail and choosing every word carefully.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1: How to interview people who are vastly different from me with compassion and an eye for detail
2: How to write stories in a compelling and insightful way
3: How to research and work hard to ensure that I get all my facts straight and represent a truth in its fullest extent

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to report in long form style, writing journalism in a way that profiled characters, built scenes, and did every detail justice. I read so many wonderful examples of long form journalism that helped shape my style as a writer, interviewer, and reporter, and spent the semester working on a single piece that encapsulated months of reporting.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class taught me the process of crafting a long-form story with a donkey, or a main character to carry the narrative along, and themes that stem from specific details within the narrative to large themes of the world: power, justice, money. Every article we were assigned showcased a mastery of long form skills in different ways, exposing me to what it would be like to practice this type of writing as a career. I learned specifically about different long form structures, how to break down language, and efffective workshopping.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so much in this course. I have never taken a journalism class, and this has been easily my favorite class I have ever taken. I became a better reader, peer editor, and writer. I learned how to effectively interview, how to write scenes and explainers, and how to engage with topics of all variety. I learned how to interact with people and ideas different from my own.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I developed and strengthened a number of skills that made me a more effective communicator, both within the bounds of journalistic writing and on a broader scale. I improved my ability to deliver complex information in an accessible way, breaking down complicated topics so they could be more digestible to readers who may have little prior experience with the subjects I'm writing about. I worked on bringing in a human voice to the stories I tell, aiming to strike a better balance between explaining the histories and complexities of real-world issues and sharing the personal experiences of people connected to those issues. I also further developed my editing skills, honing my ability to provide thoughtful and helpful feedback to other students in my class -- not just on line edits for grammar/style, but also for larger structural elements like identifying gaps in the reporting and ways to make the overall narrative more engaging and compelling.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Improved my writing skills by learning new techniques in journalistic writing 
- Changed the way I read and engage with articles 
- Learned how to deal with and persevere through challenges in the reporting process

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I was a big fan of the dedicated smaller groups for workshopping. I think they worked really well to make sure people got good feedback while also keeping the class moving efficiently. I would definitely keep them for future years.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
- Guest speakers

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Barry is the best. Like seriously the best. He's compassionate and supportive but also holds high standards and works with you granularly. The structure of the course worked phenomenally well for me, with a series of small assignments, extensive revision periods, group workshops and intentional reading assignments, all of which made weekly workloads manageable but engaging and class time useful.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Great learning environment! Very open dialogue and it felt like a safe space to share your honest thoughts and opinions, even if they might differ from your peers.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This was one of the best classes, if not the best class, I have taken at Duke. Prof. Yeoman was extremely helpful in creating a collaborative learning environment, and the 2.5 hour class always moved by super fast because of how it was split. I appreciated the workshop groups and working with peers, along with the guest speakers he invited.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The lectures were perfectly timed and engaging throughout, with breaks just when I needed them. The level of engagement with my peers was high, and allowed me to strengthen my ability to both communicate my critiques and take them in stride.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Barry created a comfortable, engaging community of writers. The class was small, and participation was a large part of the class, so I was always interested in material. We often had small group workshops where we received detailed feedback from peers on our writing, and passed around ideas regarding how we report and write. For every written assignment, Barry always offered extensive, helpful feedback. His attitude was overwhelmingly positive, while still always being constructive. I would not change the structure of the class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Yes, Barry is an incredible professor because he is engaging and can speak to his own experience in an informative and helpful way. The class, though 2.5 hours, was always broken down into learning about writing on a more general level, then discussing readings, then a lightning round of long form pieces each student enjoyed. Often there were other things tossed in the mix of class, like guest speakers or workshop periods, which also helped to make it more interesting! I'd keep this structure of teaching as it makes 2.5 hours fly by.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Barry is the best professor I have had at Duke. Barry truly cares about his students and wants us to succeed. Barry turns back assignments faster than any professor I have ever had, and his feedback is more extensive and helpful than any other professor. In class, Barry makes me want to speak and my thoughts feel valuable. The extensive feedback that Barry gives has made me a better writer. Also, the workshopping has been so helpful. Workshopping with our groups have taught me so much and helped me improve as an editor, peer, and writer. Also, the environment was fun! This class reminded me that I love learning and I love reading!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think Barry was an excellent instructor for a number of reasons, his approach to structuring the class included. I thought the workload was perfectly suited to the course, with enough required engagement with material to ensure that we were growing as readers and writers, but not so much that we were overwhelmed with the number of assignments before us. I enjoyed having one piece to work with each week that we could really dive into, and I liked having the response papers as a vehicle that prompted deeper reflection -- but not required every week to allow for some flexibility when our outside schedules got more intense. Same goes for the schedule of assignments related to the final paper -- I liked having smaller check-in excerpts due throughout the semester to keep us accountable to the reporting process, but appreciated being able to schedule interviews/reporting/writing on a timeline that worked for us up until the full draft was due near the end of the semester.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Yeoman was an incredible instructor -- I loved the structure of the course and how it matched with our progress on the semester-long project, allowing us to fully apply the material from class. He was also extremely helpful if I had questions or encountered difficulties.

response_text: Excellent reading pieces and a very lively discussion atmosphere.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: If journalism isn't stimulating, it's bad journalism. We read and produced a lot of high-level, important journalistic works and talked about them at length — for my money the most intellectually stimulating type of learning.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: A lot of diversity in stories and material presented. The classes where we talked about the ethics of journalism in groups and practiced being an editor by writing creating our own magazines were extremely intellectually stimulating and fun!

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The weekly readings and discussions were fantastic because most of the time it was one piece that we delved into with great detail, so we could understand the writer and their motives. I also really liked the workshop groups because peer feedback was helpful. This was a class where Prof. Yeoman emphasized that grading isn't his priority, but he really rewards effort and the revision process.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It was fantastic because it presented this impossible and new task (creating a longform story) in bite sized ways that made it presentable and left me with a product that I'm super proud of.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: We met with multiple prolific journalists over the semester and frequently had large class discussions on our writing, reporting, and on difficult ethical questions in our journalism. The level of participation among my peers, the small class sizes, and the opportunities for group discussion made the class very intellectually stimulating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: We read interesting writing. We learn about earthquakes, religion as power, whales, christian-rock festivals. Every class is different and exciting.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: We had great discussions!!! The lightning round at the end of each class encouraged me to engage with Longform journalism outside of class! Also, this course revived my love for reading, which has been dwindling. Remembering how much I love to read has made me very intellectually stimulated and has even helped me with my other classes.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I thought the seminar-style of the course was excellent -- I feel like we consistently had really thought-provoking discussions in this class, and everyone seemed to engage with the materials in a genuine way. Having these kinds of open discussions gave us a forum to hear insights from Barry himself, but also from our classmates, who often had just as prescient of observations to share.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Our discussions in response to the readings were my favorite part of the class. I thought that Professor Yeoman did a great job facilitating them, and I constantly learned new things from peers.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It requires a lot of dedication and a willingness to work hard outside of class, but the insight and experience you gain is well worth it. Professor Yeoman is a fantastic teacher, and if you are willing to go to office hours he is always willing to help. I would highly recommend this course to anyone with even a passing interest in journalism or writing.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Do it. Even if you have no journalism background and no interest in journalism, you will learn so much about how to be a better writer and interviewer, and will do so in a class community and with a professor that wants nothing more than to help you thrive.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a phenomenal course that I would highly recommend for both those interested in journalism and people just interested in writing. I have improved my writing significantly in this course and you will too!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Barry truly is a teacher like no other. He is kind and compassionate yet, with his decades of experience and expert eye, can help make all your confusions and problems vanish in a single conversation. I would highly recommend attending his office hours. The course is fantastic on its own, but it is truly transformative with the individual help from office hours. Regardless, this is probably my favorite class I have ever taken in my life.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would tell a future student to manage their time well. The class requires consistent, though not overwhelming, amounts of external work, either interviewing, researching, or writing, and you have to consistently work on the semester-long project to be successful. I would also tell them to just read any long form journalism they can, and to participate in class. If they do the required work, then they have nothing to worry about. The 2.5 hour classes don't feel long at all.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it! Even if you don't want to be a journalist or have a strong interest in journalism, everyone can get something out of this class. You learn how to digest information, you learn how to write informaiton, you learn how to engage in a small group. There are so many real world takeaways from taking this class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text:
TAKE IT!! The course is quite a bit of work, but it is incredibly rewarding. I looked forward to doing the work for this class and I genuinely enjoyed it. There were no busy-work assignments and I felt like I actually learned from everything that we did! 
Also, in regards to if the course was "difficult," I think it was difficult, but appropriate. I felt challenged in a good way, not in a stressful/unpleasant way.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this class!!!

response_text: Absolutely take it, even if you're not in the journalism field! You'll learn skills in writing, critical analysis, creative thinking, and all sorts of areas.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I learned how to shoot with a Bolex camera and load 16mm film. I learned how to develop film in the darkroom with chemicals. I also learned some techniques to create in-camera special effects while shooting my film.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned specific techniques related to analog filmmaking. Specific takeaways include darkroom processing of Soundstock, loading and shooting 16mm film on a Bolex camera, and basic lighting setups.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about how film works (how photos are actually created), the history of it, of course 16 mm film, how to use a Bolex camera, and how to use Premier Pro for editing

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How film works. How to do direct animation. How to edit the film with Steenbeck. How to load, and shoot with Bolex 16. How to develop Soundstock and TriX.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course was very helpful in developing technical skills related to filmmaking, editing, film processing, and shooting. Working in the darkroom was a very informative hands-on experience, as was using the Steenbeck manual editing table to splice and cut together films physically. In addition to the Steenbeck editing techniques, we were taught how to use Adobe Lightroom to edit our films digitally. I also got comfortable using the Bolex camera while making films for the class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Overall, this was my favorite course of the semester due to the positive learning environment of the class. Not only did Madison facilitate our learning through encouraging instruction and patience, but a kind and thoughtful class community was fostered through constructive critique days and collaborative--but low pressure--group projects. Overall, I looked forward to coming to class every week and learning alongside everyone.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think the structure of the assignments from very basic to a final full film is really helpful because you get to learn how to use certain tools and machines early on and then it culminates into a final project.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Hill provided a good balance of lecturing (on the history, theory, technology, etc. of filmmaking) and practical application of the concepts we learned in class. Each class session felt like a constructive progression from the previous one. question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: in class shooting and hands on exercises

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I found the course stimulating first by nature of the subject, as 16mm analog filmmaking is a topic of interest to me and one with which I had no prior experience. question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a fun intro level course to 16mm film! If you want time to do some hands on art, this is the place. Shooting and developing can be a little stressful, but Madison was always very responsive and helpful when reached out to. Make sure you take notes in class to prepare for shooting, and start your projects far before they are due.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Please take this course! Madison is a wonderful instructor who will introduce you to the joys and intricacies of analog filmmaking. Although analog can be frustrating at times, this course allows you to experience both the excitement of getting it right (film turning out as intended) and the mistakes that are inherent to 16mm filmmaking, without the stress of having to be the perfect filmmaker. Instead, grace is given for all students to learn the medium and experiment with their own creative impulses.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class is what you make it - you can really learn a lot if you do the readings, participate, and are intentional about your film - and it's really fun!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would suggest this course to anyone interested or excited about filmmaking, whether analog or digital. The 16mm process is challenging but rewarding, and a good way to explore both practical and creative skills.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the proper ways to go about trauma-informed interviewing. I've learned to stay quiet and sit in the awkward silence. I've learned to be skeptical but also understanding and vulnerable.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I want to use these spaces carefully because I want to emphasize the importance of keeping Barry Yeoman as an adjunct and heavily involved in the Duke community. I learned three distinct things that are valuable as skills as a journalist, as well as skills as a person. Barry really taught me the importance of listening. He did this in several ways. He incorporated voices of other journalists, he incorporated his own experience, and then he challenged us to interview each other. All three of these activities pointed towards the importance of listening actively and what that looks like. Barry also taught us about trauma-informed interviewing. By going over his own mistakes from the past, he demonstrated how easy it is to come across the wrong way to someone who has experienced trauma. The lesson felt real and genuine, and made approaching difficult subjects must easier. Finally, Barry taught me the importance of research. Going into any interaction whether an interview or an expert opinion, knowing the work and experience of the person on the other side is a demonstration of respect. Barry was critical to my passion and love for writing.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

We also always had "lightning rounds" if we wanted to share something we had read or listened to over the past week. He also was so constructive and kind with feedback on our journalistic pieces.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Yeoman guided us throughout the process of finding interviewee's, preparing for the interview, conducting it, analyzing your notes, doing follow-up, and writing the piece. Examples from his own work and the work of the guest speakers were really useful as I developed my own approach. I really liked the selection of readings and while I didn't resonate with every single one, it was nice to be able to come to class and hear what other people had to say about them that made me think of the writing/audio in a new way. I like the structure of a discussion-based class where I feel like everyone was comfortable to ask any questions at any point.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Yeoman explained to us how to go about finding current news stories we were interested in to then explore for our pieces throughout the semester - coming into the class, I was nervous I wouldn't find a topic I would be interested in doing 2 articles on, but quickly I learnt that shouldn't have been a worry. He also led us through every aspect of interviewing people, including the ethics, the actual dialogue, how to prepare, and so on. He also listened to our interviews and gave us personal advice for what to ask our interviewees next, as well as what specifically to work on. I would keep it all for future years.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor was very helpful and always able to provide feedback. He gave us helpful feedback on our assignments and was always very prompt in responding to emails. Thestructure of the Course, going from informative interviews to narrative interviews, helped build my journalism interviewing skills. Hearing from guest speakers who are journalists also helped me learn more, as did the long-form article readings. I would keep the assignments the way they are, I really liked getting actual feedback on my audio recording of interviews. I liked that we got to choose a social justice topic and really focus on it.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Barry was an incredible professor. I greatly enjoyed the structure of the assignments in which we had a semester-long topic but interviewed a multitude of different people, and I appreciated that the evaluation was largely on the interviewing piece, as that was what we had learned about in class. I also loved the readings and podcasts we did in preparation for the class sessions and thought that the class size was perfect for being able to thoroughly discuss and practice good interviewing and have ethical debates about journalistic practices.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Barry was extremely supportive and is clearly willing to put in as much effort and time as you need. The evaluation system allowed for a low-stress environment while also forcing you to do real work and accomplish significant things (like doing a series of intimate interviews with a stranger). I liked the structure of the course as well, with interviews of advocates coming before the narrative, personal interviews. It allowed me to get more comfortable with interviewing by speaking with people who didn't need as much guidance from the interviewer (me!).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Learned how there are a multitude of stories behind language, terminology, and our understanding of the environment. 
2. The origin of colonialism and the anthropocene, and how this history shapes our modern outlooks on the environment and environmental justice. (Example - reviewing the influence of darwinism and what is "natural" and "just", etc.)
3. Narratives matter, and there are many of them. The differences between writers such as Locke, Darwin, Thoreau, Simmard, Kimmerer, Marsh, and more are astounding and reflect different understandings of the right of humans to take from this Earth and ultimately what the consequences of this become. These highlight how environmental issues cannot be divorced from questions of power, ethics, and equity. These different narratives allows us to evaluate historical paradigms (like commodification of nature) in context of the issues of today. These narratives show that environmental justice is not a single story and its ever-evolving to include and prioritize different ecological and social living systems. 
4. Environmental justice is not just about nature or wilderness. It's not just about economic opportunity. It's everything that surrounds us. It's about recognizing the right of everyone and everything, and the impact it leaves on everything else. It's about recognizing marginalized communities and preservation of spaces. It's about policymaking that reflects a commitment to the well-being of all things, as all things are interrelated. It shows the interconnected framework that integrates social equity, ecological health, and the well-being of all living systems. Environmental justice transcends any single issue. At its core, environmental justice is about reimagining the boundaries of "us"/"them"/"we" and instead honoring the reciprocity that must come with our globe through shared responsibility.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think about Duke with new context of its history within Durham. I also learned about how to think about ameliorating the environmental burdens of certain communities. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I LOVED THIS CLASS. One of my favorites at Duke, and Dr. Priscilla Wald was the reason for this. She guides the class effectively while also letting the class flow when my peers and I were discussing related things. For example, the day after the election was solely a time to reflect and she let us talk about whatever we wanted instead of "having" to do the exercises associated with the readings for that day. I also particularly loved that the class was outside most of the time in the gardens and around Duke/Durham. Keep all methods of instruction. I can't say enough how much I loved this class and the hospitable environment we had. She also gave us opportunities to work on creative pieces without any reprecussions, and discussion posts had no particular guidelines we had to follow.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I loved having class in the gardens. I would definitely keep the field trip components. I would also keep the open class structure. This is the first class that I've been in that was able to facilitate such effective open communication. Breaking off into small groups and then reporting back ensured that everyone was involved in the discussion and made the discussion feel very casual. I think that this format, as well as sitting outside in a circle, helped everyone feel able and willing to contribute. Finally, I loved that we were able to adjust the schedule to take time to discuss stressful current events.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:

2) I gained insight into how the current culture and environment of the journalism landscape incentivizes some journalists to plagiarize or fabricate facts in their stories, like Stephen Glass.
3) I'm now able to better emphasize in what way the journalist of an article is biased—and I can also avow that all journalists and people are biased in some way. For example, you can be biased towards the truth.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I found that the course struck a perfect balance between class speakers and lecturing from Bill. And throughout both mediums, we were continuously empowered as students to ask questions and contribute to the discussion. Specifically, I think the class speakers are what helped to facilitate student learning. Not only did we hear from journalists and journalist experts, but we also heard from students like us who have ventured into journalism and encountered its problems from a fresh perspective. We heard from right-wing-leaning media owners. We heard from people who were impacted by right-wing media rabbit holes firsthand. Essentially, we got a variety of perspectives on the state of journalism, and this empowered us to use these testimonies to form our own conclusions.I also think all of the writing assignments clearly signaled relevance to the class, and they helped to apply and facilitate our learning. The individual prompts were also well-timed with what we were currently learning about or where we were in the course syllabus/timeline.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

Then ask Bill or your peers!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
