question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained a lot of unique insights from media and industry experts on the state of media and our society today. I got to write a few very fun papers and ideate create solutions to very challenging problems.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about the world of journalism and the current issues the industry faces with trust and retaining ethical standards of content that reflect well on journalism as a whole. I also learned about different mediums of journalism and how to write better papers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned a lot more about misinformation in the news, which I had not previously known a lot about.
I learned how to construct meaningful, insightful questions for guest speakers, in order to maximise what I gain from these lectures.
I developed how to write in a way that is concise and gets meaning across to the reader of my papers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Better understanding of the media & journalism industry, a deep dive into some of the issues surrounding trust & polarization, writing tips, creative solutions-oriented thinking

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Critical media literacy skills, ability to write lively and compelling papers, interesting approaches to media and business

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: On the first day of this course, Professor Adair anonymously asked us how much news we consume on a given day... I was one of the students who consumed 0 articles/day and now I consume 5+ articles/day... all because of this class! Even though the class can be "depressing," as it explores the topic of lack of trust in journalism, it actually made me enjoy reading the news for the first time ever. Instead of reading a news article and only thinking about the subject matter of the article, I now think about how the article fits with the news outlet's business goals (ex: Athletic articles in NYT), whether it is "solutions journalism," whether it could contribute to the problem of "news avoidance," etc.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Entering this class I had no experience in journalism and was apprehensive of my ability to interact and engage. However, this class was an incredible introduction and inspiration to journalism. The flow of the class from the structures of journalism to innovative solutions was logical to follow. First, I gained knowledge about journalism ethics, the different types of reporting, and interviewing jargon that I will take with me into my professional career. However, these barely covered the surface of the deep insights I gained into the implications of partisan media and the challenges all media companies face. The discussions of Fox compared to CNN and MSNBC were eye-opening and going deeper into more unique media sources allowed me to interact with formats I had not seen before.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I developed an appreciation for the role of local news in my community.
I developed an understanding of the issues facing journalism.
I learned about the different forms of journalism, both traditional and non-traditional.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I think I learned how to navigate the media more vigilantly. 
I definitely developed deeper critical thinking skills when it comes to how I consume news or "the media". 
I have learned how to apply these skills in different formats of media.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a deeper understanding of the foundations of journalism and journalistic principles, the necessary role fact-checking plays in journalism as well as in our larger democracy, and the evolution of the journalism industry as well as the threats it currently faces.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Guest speakers taught me a lot, but felt like some class lectures were not as stimulating as they could have been. Would have liked to see current events consistently integrated into slides/lectures, as opposed to just having one or two lectures dedicated to dissecting Olivia Nuzzi and Mark Robinson or the election. Also could have included pieces from the Daily Show, Fox & Friends, etc. Also, Phil Boyce was an excellent guest and I would have liked to see some more conservative speakers or assignments from/for conservative sources (though I appreciate it's probably difficult to find people willing to talk to a liberal Duke class).

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I appreciated hearing the opinions of my peers and would encourage opportunities for us to talk to each other rather than at the teacher. This being said, I think we would've benefited more from group discussions and breaking off into smaller groups so that everyone was able to share their ideas and it could've been more conversational rather than one voice in a big lecture, one at a time. That would've at least been more stimulating to me.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I thoroughly enjoyed how relevant this class was. In my experience, it is rare to be in a class in which the professor is consistently addressing current issues/events. I especially enjoyed this given the recent election cycle. Keeping up with current events is something that I value, so being able to do so through assignments, lectures, and class discussions was highly enjoyable. My only suggestion would be to make the powerpoints more engaging or perhaps limiting them altogether. Although I understand the informational value they bring, they can also not be particularly intellectually stimulating when taking up the entire class period.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I do feel fortunate as this semester felt the most important and relevant to take this class as it was in the months leading up to what feels like the most important election in our lifetimes. Everything we discussed felt perfectly timed and helped inform me to what was going on in the world around me.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

response_text: The course is best when you are active in discussions, sharing personal beliefs and scrutinizing the beliefs of others to best challenge our preconceived notions about journalism and its biases.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it!!!!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you're looking to increase your knowledge on the news industry and become a more critical consumer of news, definitely take this course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you can, wait to take this class with Tash. It will be one of your best classes at Duke!!!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Come with questions, show you're interested, go to office hours. (When there's a guest speaker on Zoom, I found the readers to be pretty optional since Tash will start half the class with his own questions.)Also, forget everything you've ever learned about academic writing. It won't be useful for this course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Highly recommend. The weekly homework is not a big commitment — it typically involves reading a few articles and short excerpts from books. There are three major papers, but they are only 6-7 pages and have interesting prompts. You'll learn so much about news and journalism. Tash is also very nice and clearly cares about his students.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I 100% would recommend this class to everyone and anyone. If you do decide to take this course make sure you come in willing to participate in class discussions and really experiment with the material. Do the readings. They are all interesting and relate so well to the material that we cover as a class. Don't be afraid to ask the guest speakers questions. They all gave fantastic answers to our questions, and with those we were able to guide our learning in the course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this course! This is, by far, one of my favorite courses I have ever taken at Duke. Professor Tash is phenomenal and is truly so knowledgeable and experienced in the field. You will learn so much from and his insights, while having lots of fun along the way. If you are interested in journalism, this class will expose you to so many interesting people and topics, which will undoubtedly support your development. If you are not interested in journalism as a career, you will still learn so many interesting things about an industry that impacts our society on a deep level. You will become a more critical consumer of news, and benefits from the skills learned throughout the course in your every day life.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is an incredible class that will allow you to understand the value of news in our society as well as the challenges facing it in the future. Professor Tash is a kind, engaging, and incredibly accomplished professor who wants the students to get the most out of the class. I could not recommend this course enough.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Buy in – this is seriously the best class you may take at Duke, so don't take it for granted.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Absolutely take this course! It was hands down my favorite course I've taken at Duke, and has made me seriously consider going into journalism, or incorporating journalism in my future in some capacity (Prior to this course, I had never even considered going into journalism). Paul Tash is an amazing instructor, and you would be so fortunate to take one of his classes. The course was challenging, but in a way that makes you feel like you're learning and growing. If you put in the work, you'll be rewarded. Furthermore, Professor Tash is extremely open to meeting for office hours, and provides great feedback on assignments.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take the class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a class worth sitting back and just genuinely enjoying. I think it is truly one of the more special opportunities at Sanford.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you have the opportunity to take the course with Paul Tash, do not pass it up. It is totally worth it!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the journalistic imperative of objectivity and impartiality, as well as other editorial standards and why they are so crucial.I gained insight into a wide range of current and historical topics that have played major roles in journalism and the broader world.I widened my perspective about journalism and a lot of recent developments, partially through the regular guest lectures that were informative.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Writing, research, synthesis. This course challenged me in ways I was not expecting. As a senior, I did not feel like I had much to learn, but the daily discussion and 3 core assignments pushed me to think deeper and produce a higher quality product.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze news to a much deeper extent. I now have a much deeper insight into how the journalism world actually works. I learned about the current landscape of the journalism world.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This was the best course I have ever taken at Duke. I learned how to read interresting articles, analyze news sources for credibility, and have intellectually engaging discussions about them.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class taught me to think critically about the news, engage with current events, and write concisely.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about local journalism, about journalism ethics, and about ways to make the news more optimistic.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: evaluating the news more analytically, historical precedent about the news, journalism specifics from the different speakers

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think above all this course taught me the importance of thinking holistically due to the fact that it gave me a greater appreciation for the process of journalism. 2 other things I learned include the importance of being articulate and up-to-date on current affairs as well as the importance of listening and trying to understand opposing viewpoints to the greatest of extents. Without opposing viewpoints, we wouldn't have journalism.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I've learned about the structures of newspapers - how they are divided and structured. 
I have learned about what good journalism is about - having courage, curiosity, and conviction when pursuing the truth.
I've learned about the different types of journalism, from objective news reporting to morning bulletins and opinion editorials, and how journalism can shape history.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to think critically about journalism and journalistic issues; how to research and form evidence-supported opinions; the values of journalism

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Many of the topics we explored in this course are subjects I engage with daily in my role as news editor of The Chronicle. However, I enjoyed being able to hear the varying perspectives of my peers -- many of whom do not have extensive journalism backgrounds -- on some of the ethical questions I am consistently grappling with. The subjects we discussed included how news agendas are determined and why it's important to balance the slate of coverage on a given day, the importance of anonymous sources and dangers associated with using them too frequently, the obligation to thoroughly fact-check all reporting, and much more.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how journalists think in regards to how they write, develop and produce news. One thing that I learned that stands out is that "facts are expensive, opinions are cheap." Being sure to take the time to research is important especially when crafting stories. I also learned the importance of clarity when writing and when reporting. And the importance of follow up questions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about the principles, economics and different mediums of journalism and how those coincide in a digital world that is constantly evolving.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
The Role of Journalism in Society - What function does the news play? How has it shaped history? How do people interact with it? How has it changed?
Interdisciplinary thinking - How to approach complex challenges relating to justice and morality in a world constrained by business and personal influence 
Writing - How to edit our writing to ensure we make every word count and aren't redundant

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course helped a lot with my writing. Professor Tash took the time to read my paper, mark it up, and offer in-depth feedback.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This was my first journalism class, and I learned a ton about what the field is actually like, the types of stories produced, and how much variety there is in terms of long-form writing, TV broadcasting, podcasts, etc. This class also helped me work on my own writing skills through feedback on my essays, to just getting to read a vast collection of work over the semester and learn from those authors.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to write in a less academic/more journalistic way, critically ask questions, and critically approach news.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I had know and understood the threats that journalism faces, but I learned more about the complexity and evolution of these threats. It is an insight that I will carry with me as I consume media coverage for the rest of my life. In addition to refining my media literacy skills, I developed news ways of thinking when it comes to understanding the journalism industry. It is not just newspapers and TV outlets, but a blooming industry full of startups and people who simply want to share stories that are interesting to them.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course did an excellent job of pushing students to think with perspective. As the semester continued on, I realized that in class discussion there was no right answer for anything we were discussing. Debating the moral ethics of journalism is no easy feat, and this class kept me engaged with the world around me, improving not just practical skills like my writing, but also helped me become more of a global citizen.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Incredible insight into the journalism world and profession, both through Professor Tash's experience and the amazing speakers
- Writing development: I have never had a professor take so much time and attention in helping us write better. 
- Hearing opinions and experiences differing from mine in respectful and productive ways

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot through the course of the semester. In fact, as my first and only journalism class of college, I feel grateful it was this one. I learned to think of news as a moral battleground, and received a well-lit tour of the horizon. I learned about partisanship in the news media and to be conscious of framing. I also learned about several important stories on an international, national and local level. Most importantly, I learned about what good journalism and writing looks like, and some tips and tricks to get there.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to analyze news academically, journalism ethics and morals, ways in which to help the journalism industry in the future

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Synthesizing readings, research and writing skills, creative and critical thinking

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to be a conscious consumer of the news, how to develop my journalistic writing skills, and how to analyze different news articles.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a tremendous amount about the anatomy of the news business from national to local scales, the shortcomings and bright spots of the industry, and what strong, proper journalism should look like. The guest speakers were phenomenal, shedding light on some of the most pivotal moments in the history of journalism and the impact they have on our world. It was especially interesting to hear these guest speakers speak about the actual process of launching an investigation or expose of a particular subject. This class puts into perspective the indispensable role journalism plays in our society, and that we as a citizenry have an obligation to do our part to preserve that.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: As a STEM major / not having a pub pol or journalism background, this class was super interesting! I learned about the complexities and challenges surrounding both news reporting and journalistic consumption. My favorite aspects dealt with the discussions surrounding the evolution of the news -- how topics such as fact-checking, polarization, and bias have changed drastically in the last decade and especially the last few years. The class was focused on present-day trends not history which I liked.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: the threats to journalism and it's link to the current political climate, new ways to explore better journalism in the future, the skill of clear and journalistic writing

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Improved reading, writing, and reasearch skills

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Analyzing news articles in depth, beyond what is expected/usually done, presenting findings well, engaging in class activities used to make us think deeply about the news that we consume.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Paul Tash is a wonderful professor and human being - he is so passionate about the subject and his students and was always willing to meet with us outside of class. Plus he is EXTREMELY well connected and brought in incredible speakers.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Tash is a master of this craft, and I could not be more grateful to learn from someone not only as experienced but also as compassionate as him. Given his career, he could have easily "checked out" or condescended upon our class; instead, he treated each and every person with kindness and respect. His feedback on my assignments has been invaluable, and I have truly found every aspect of this course helpful.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the open discussions we often had in class. These allowed us to engage directly with the larger ethical questions posed by the case studies we examined in each week's readings instead of spending time reviewing the simple facts of the case, and to hear our classmates' opinions on the decisions journalists made and whether they were appropriate. The guest speakers were also phenomenal and a highlight of the course.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

response_text: The fantastic guest speakers that we had not only demonstrated the academic strength of the JAM program and its professors, but did a great job structuring the course to connect our lectures/readings with real world speakers. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Tash created a robust environment for learning with the facilitated conversations. This definitely contributed to the liveliness of the classroom, but it was Tash who kept us engaged with stories, asking us to dig deeper in our responses, and carefully choosing what material to assign to us.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

response_text: Professor Tash comes into the semester with a goal: to make this one of the most memorable classes of your college experience. And considering that I want to pursue a career in journalism, each class was an opportunity to learn more about the profession.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think the paper prompts made this course intellectually stimulating. The papers challenged me to challenge conventional wisdom.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: We talked about real, current, and pressing concerns in the journalism industry, which have implications for our current democracy and livelihood.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: All of the topics were interesting, the 2.5 hour block is just tough.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The variety of works that we read, hearing from acclaimed leaders in the industry, and being challenged to imagine what decisions we would have made in the writing room all worked to make this class very stimulating. Professor Tash did a fantastic job of explaining the industry, providing real-world examples, and being supportive as we all learned throughout the semester. And Professor Buckley was an ever-present addition that echoed those same sentiments of support and genuine care to see us succeed and grow.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The range of guest speakers and assignments of current event readings.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class was stimulating because of the discussion it encouraged and the many ethical questions it raised throughout the semester.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Like I stated before, this class made me think so much about how there is no right answer in many of our discussions. You are constantly being pushed to think outside the box, and realize the impact journalism has, and the threats it faces. My favorite class to date was when we got to pretend to be the Pulitzer Prize board, and debated a new winner. It was so interesting to hear everyone's notes and opinions, and create a diverse perspective on the different pieces. Professor Tash's experience sitting on the board himself added to the depth of the discussion.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This was the best class I have taken at Duke regarding speakers with such an impressive and widely valuable set of experiences and skills. I was blown away week after week by how exciting the speakers were. This was my first journalism class, and it immediately convinced me to minor in the subject! Professor Tash is very experienced and brought amazing stories about his time in the field which captivated the class. I know at times the conversation slowed a little bit too much for some people, but I was always interested.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It was very much stimulating.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Milligan was one of the most helpful and knowledgeable professors I’ve had at my time at Duke- and I’m a BME major. He had a very clear and detailed lesson plan that got introductory filmmakers caught up with the more advanced students in the class, and even offered workshops on various things like lighting, camera work, and editing throughout the year to bolster our learning. I think it was so cool we were able to use the film studio for every class, as instead of just watching and discussing film pieces we were able to create and learn as we made film together.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Learned how there are a multitude of stories behind language, terminology, and our understanding of the environment. 
2. The origin of colonialism and the anthropocene, and how this history shapes our modern outlooks on the environment and environmental justice. (Example - reviewing the influence of darwinism and what is "natural" and "just", etc.)
3. Narratives matter, and there are many of them. The differences between writers such as Locke, Darwin, Thoreau, Simmard, Kimmerer, Marsh, and more are astounding and reflect different understandings of the right of humans to take from this Earth and ultimately what the consequences of this become. These highlight how environmental issues cannot be divorced from questions of power, ethics, and equity. These different narratives allows us to evaluate historical paradigms (like commodification of nature) in context of the issues of today. These narratives show that environmental justice is not a single story and its ever-evolving to include and prioritize different ecological and social living systems. 
4. Environmental justice is not just about nature or wilderness. It's not just about economic opportunity. It's everything that surrounds us. It's about recognizing the right of everyone and everything, and the impact it leaves on everything else. It's about recognizing marginalized communities and preservation of spaces. It's about policymaking that reflects a commitment to the well-being of all things, as all things are interrelated. It shows the interconnected framework that integrates social equity, ecological health, and the well-being of all living systems. Environmental justice transcends any single issue. At its core, environmental justice is about reimagining the boundaries of "us"/"them"/"we" and instead honoring the reciprocity that must come with our globe through shared responsibility.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think about Duke with new context of its history within Durham. I also learned about how to think about ameliorating the environmental burdens of certain communities. For example, we spent a class using Beaufort as a case study of towns where environmental injustices have occurred, and we brainstormed ways that things could have done differently and we looked at all of the factors involved in both creating and solving the problem

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I LOVED THIS CLASS. One of my favorites at Duke, and Dr. Priscilla Wald was the reason for this. She guides the class effectively while also letting the class flow when my peers and I were discussing related things. For example, the day after the election was solely a time to reflect and she let us talk about whatever we wanted instead of "having" to do the exercises associated with the readings for that day. I also particularly loved that the class was outside most of the time in the gardens and around Duke/Durham. Keep all methods of instruction. I can't say enough how much I loved this class and the hospitable environment we had. She also gave us opportunities to work on creative pieces without any reprecussions, and discussion posts had no particular guidelines we had to follow.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: She is the best! She is so passionate about teaching and cares for each and every one of her students. She is one of the sweetest professors I've ever had!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I loved having class in the gardens. We also had a lot of field trips, and being able to see the areas that we were talking about in class, like Downtown Durham or the campus farm, was super helpful. I would definitely keep the field trip components. I would also keep the open class structure. This is the first class that I've been in that was able to facilitate such effective open communication. Breaking off into small groups and then reporting back ensured that everyone was involved in the discussion and made the discussion feel very casual. I think that this format, as well as sitting outside in a circle, helped everyone feel able and willing to contribute. Finally, I loved that we were able to adjust the schedule to take time to discuss stressful current events.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I sincerely enjoyed this course and love that it is not a standard Duke course, but an endowed course offered every election season. I think everyone-- regardless of major, etc-- should take this course!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This was my first class using Premiere Pro. I got an intro course on editing professional-looking videos and collaborating with other editors. Another thing I learned was the difference between campaigns backed by big money and grass roots campaigns. Lastly I learned about the barriers women face to get elected into office and what can be done to encourage more women to run and win.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked that we had an open discussion format. Both professors emphasized respect and open-mindedness, which made me more comfortable to share my thoughts/opinions, even if I felt they were underwhelming. I also enjoyed that we made documentary-style episodes. I felt that I was able to express a creative side to myself that I am not usually able to do through my other Duke courses. Moreover, I like that this was a relatively small class as it allowed us all to bond in a way that would not have been possible with a bigger class, while maintaining fruitful discussion. Finally, arguably my favorite part about this course were the class speakers. I loved engaging with women leaders from various states and sectors of the public. I learned the most from them and their interviews.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class pushed me to think about gender and ecology in ways I had never considered- how plants communicate, the importance of reciprocity, and practices of collective care. I also learned how to make a film from start to finish: interviewing people, editing footage, adding music—skills I had never explored before. As a computer science major, this was the kind of class I never knew I needed. At Duke, it’s easy to stay in the bubble of econ, finance, and compsci, but courses like this are what the Trinity Arts & Sciences education is really about—broadening your perspective and becoming more well-rounded. As I head into senior year and speak with past seniors, I’m thinking more about what I want to take with me from Duke. For me, that means building deeper relationships and being more present in the community I’ve lived in for four years. This class helped me start doing that.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: What did we not learn? We engaged with texts from feminist theory to science fiction about aliens, we presented and discussed weekly, we worked together on the Duke Campus Farm, we made sauerkraut together, we worked closely and intensively in small groups and with community partners and activists to make 10 minute documentary films. We learned how to use Premiere Pro, how to connect with community members unaffiliated with Duke who we would otherwise never have met, and how to mesh all of the experiences from this class into one hugely fulfilling project.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: 1) I learned video editing skills in Premiere Pro. 2) I learned how to interview people and how to guide them to answer questions that are part of a broader theme. 3) I improved my teamwork skills and to play a supportive role when working with others.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Through this course, I developed (and fine-tuned) filmmaking, editing, and software skills by curating student-led film projects in collaboration with community partners in the Triangle area. I gained insights from course texts that engaged with queer and feminist theory, developing new ways of thinking about the current climate crisis, of being in relation with one another, and how (both tangibly and theoretically) to live and embody these concepts (not just read, think, and write about them). I learned how to work collaboratively on a long-term creative project in such a way that builds on our individual and collective strengths. I explored new elements of our relationship to our environment, from our biological traits to the science behind our gut-brain connection.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Of all of the classes I took this semester, this class provided me one of the most enriching and insightful experiences. From our weekly assigned readings and discussion posts, I learned how to critically read and analyze complex texts related to ecology and feminist studies. From our visits to the Duke Campus Farm, I learned about the farm's history and also engaged with specific practices including mulching, weeding, and broad-forking. Throughout the process of completing our final project, I learned how to make a short documentary and all of the moving parts that such an initiative requires (eg. recording interviews, writing narration, drafting a storyboard, editing).

I was also pushed outside of my comfort

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Each day of class, Saskia and Lauren began with a prompt, encouraging us to reflect on something new or exciting or even pick up on a thread or concept from the previous week. What seemed like such a small moment at the beginning of each class ended up bringing us closer together, celebrating our individual wins as a class and offering glimpses of joy when weeks were particularly difficult. Saskia and Lauren united us, creating an environment centered around care, community, and curiosity, creating space for intellectual growth and even humility, recognizing that we do not always have the answers. Lauren and Saskia were always available to field questions about our film, about the content of the course that we found particularly challenging, fascinating, or frustrating. Lauren offered a space to develop new film editing skills using Premiere Pro, providing countless opportunities to meet during office hours to learn new workarounds and shortcuts to enhance the power of our project.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Lauren and Saskia's teaching made this class thoroughly stimulating. question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would say that you'll be a different person by the end of the semester. question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This was truly the most powerful, rewarding, collaborative, and intellectually challenging course I have taken in my four years at Duke. I recommend this course to those interested in gender studies, environmental justice, queer theory, farming, especially if these are new or unfamiliar concepts to you.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I could not recommend this class enough to any student who is interested in the climate, ecology, gender theory, community-engaged learning, or documentary filmmaking. Whether a student has a background in these subjects or an interest they want to explore, this class offers such a special opportunity to engage with any or all of these areas. Taking this class taught me how to consider gender theory and climate change - two topics that I had not previously assumed to be connected - in relation to each other. It was unforgettable to be able to learn by physically being at the Duke Campus Farm and building relationships with the people working there. This class showed me what it can look like to try something new, become more aware of my own positionality as a student, and engage with my environment (including the land and its people) more conscientiously.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so much from this class. It was truly transformative—I developed new ways of thinking about climate change through the lens of gender and sexuality, which I'd never thought of before. It opened up my mind! I learned how to make a documentary, which was a feat.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned SO MUCH in this course!! Not only was I able to learn about the theory of feminism, environmental activism, etc, I was also able to apply my knowledge in a meaningful way with a product to show for it. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class pushed me to think about gender and ecology in ways I had never considered- how plants communicate, the importance of reciprocity, and practices of collective care. I also learned how to make a film from start to finish: interviewing people, editing footage, adding music—skills I had never explored before. As a computer science major, this was the kind of class I never knew I needed. At Duke, it’s easy to stay in the bubble of econ, finance, and compsci, but courses like this are what the Trinity Arts & Sciences education is really about—broadening your perspective and becoming more well-rounded. As I head into senior year and speak with past seniors, I’m thinking more about what I want to take with me from Duke. For me, that means building deeper relationships and being more present in the community I’ve lived in for four years. This class helped me start doing that.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Filmmaking
- Critical thinking about text, filmmaking, artistry, lived experiences

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: What did we not learn? We engaged with texts from feminist theory to science fiction about aliens, we presented and discussed weekly, we worked together on the Duke Campus Farm, we made sauerkraut together, we worked closely and intensively in small groups and with community partners and activists to make 10 minute documentary films. We learned how to use Premiere Pro, how to connect with community members unaffiliated with Duke who we would otherwise never have met, and how to mesh all of the experiences from this class into one hugely fulfilling project.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: 1) I learned video editing skills in Premiere Pro. 2) I learned how to interview people and how to guide them to answer questions that are part of a broader theme. 3) I improved my teamwork skills and to play a supportive role when working with others.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Through this course, I developed (and fine-tuned) filmmaking, editing, and software skills by curating student-led film projects in collaboration with community partners in the Triangle area. I gained insights from course texts that engaged with queer and feminist theory, developing new ways of thinking about the current climate crisis, of being in relation with one another, and how (both tangibly and theoretically) to live and embody these concepts (not just read, think, and write about them). I learned how to work collaboratively on a long-term creative project in such a way that builds on our individual and collective strengths. I explored new elements of our relationship to our environment, from our biological traits to the science behind our gut-brain connection.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Of all of the classes I took this semester, this class provided me one of the most enriching and insightful experiences. From our weekly assigned readings and discussion posts, I learned how to critically read and analyze complex texts related to ecology and feminist studies. From our visits to the Duke Campus Farm, I learned about the farm's history and also engaged with specific practices including mulching, weeding, and broad-forking. Throughout the process of completing our final project, I learned how to make a short documentary and all of the moving parts that such an initiative requires (eg. recording interviews, writing narration, drafting a storyboard, editing).

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: These instructors were two of the best I have had at Duke and were really detrimental to my learning and progression in the course. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructors were just incredible. As a junior at Duke, this is easily the most profound course I have taken. The instructors were attentive, caring, and knowledgeable. Saskia helped guide and provoke discussions with thoughtful questions and a diverse array of activities to simulate our thinking. Lauren had so much insight to share and I could not imagine someone more supportive to learn filmmaking for the first time from. They were both receptive and open to helping students however possible and whenever necessary. I always felt excited going to class because we were doing something new and talking about something meaningful, which expanded my broader knowledge of climate, justice, and their intersection. We participated in a lot of hands-on activities, like visiting the Duke Campus Farm and making sauerkraut, that helped me grasp texts in a fun and meaningful way. I loved this experiential aspect as well as the final project, which was incredibly rewarding and insightful and allowed me to truly connect with the Durham community for the first time. I was also pushed outside of my comfort

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The co-teaching style of this class was perfect for the structure and material. Professor Cornes engages more directly with the readings, while Professor Henschel handles the film end of things. The activities like the trip to the farm and sauerkraut workshop were not only bonding and fun but also relevant to the material and intellectually engaging. The film was the biggest part of the class, and it was one of the most challenging but also most fulfilling projects I've ever done.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This class was structured very well. It was a great balance of experiential learning at the Duke Campus Farm, creative exploration while filmmaking, and intellectual stimulation through course readings. I would definitely keep the visits to the Duke Campus Farm and filmmaking lessons for future classes. Through these unique experiences, and considering that people from different majors enroll in the class, they all have the opportunity to try something new and maybe find a new passion, like I did for filmmaking.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Each day of class, Saskia and Lauren began with a prompt, encouraging us to reflect on something new or exciting or even pick up on a thread or concept from the previous week. What seemed like such a small moment at the beginning of each class ended up bringing us closer together, celebrating our individual wins as a class and offering glimpses of joy when weeks were particularly difficult. Saskia and Lauren united us, creating an environment centered around care, community, and curiosity, creating space for intellectual growth and even humility, recognizing that we do not always have the answers. Lauren and Saskia were always available to field questions about our film, about the content of the course that we found particularly challenging, fascinating, or frustrating. Lauren offered a space to develop new film editing skills using Premiere Pro, providing countless opportunities to meet during office hours to learn new workarounds and shortcuts to enhance the power of our project.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class was stimulating because we were doing something different every week. One week, we would go to the Duke Campus Farm and participate in the Community Work Days. question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I found this course's multimedia approach to be highly intellectually stimulating. It allowed us to cut through and across academic houses, from intellectual “authorities” on the Anthropocene to visionary Indigenous thinkers such as Robin Kimmerer and Tommy Pico's powerful poetics.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Lauren and Saskia's teaching made this class thoroughly stimulating. Whether it was reading our discussion posts each week, asking thought-provoking questions to encourage class conversation, or presenting class concepts through engaging presentations, Saskia helped cultivate an environment where students were excited and interested in what we were learning. Lauren, likewise, brought her invaluable technical expertise when supporting our learning as beginner filmmakers. I greatly valued her feedback on our one-minute videos and full-length documentary, and our final project benefitted immensely from her insight. My favorite aspect of this class was the ability to visit and directly engage with the Duke Campus Farm community. question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would say that you'll be a different person by the end of the semester. I would also say that taking this class will make you see the world in a different way. For me, it made me realize that films are not just for entertainment; they can play an activist role and be a form of resistance.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This was truly the most powerful, rewarding, collaborative, and intellectually challenging course I have taken in my four years at Duke. I recommend this course to those interested in gender studies, environmental justice, queer theory, farming, especially if these are new or unfamiliar concepts to you.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I could not recommend this class enough to any student who is interested in the climate, ecology, gender theory, community-engaged learning, or documentary filmmaking. Whether a student has a background in these subjects or an interest they want to explore, this class offers such a special opportunity to engage with any or all of these areas. Taking this class taught me how to consider gender theory and climate change - two topics that I had not previously assumed to be connected - in relation to each other. It was unforgettable to be able to learn by physically being at the Duke Campus Farm and building relationships with the people working there. This class showed me what it can look like to try something new, become more aware of my own positionality as a student, and engage with my environment (including the land and its people) more conscientiously.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I want to use these spaces carefully because I want to emphasize the importance of keeping Barry Yeoman as an adjunct and heavily involved in the Duke community. I learned three distinct things that are valuable as skills as a journalist, as well as skills as a person. Barry really taught me the importance of listening. He did this in several ways. He incorporated voices of other journalists, he incorporated his own experience, and then he challenged us to interview each other. All three of these activities pointed towards the importance of listening actively and what that looks like. Barry also taught us about trauma-informed interviewing. By going over his own mistakes from the past, he demonstrated how easy it is to come across the wrong way to someone who has experienced trauma. The lesson felt real and genuine, and made approaching difficult subjects must easier. Finally, Barry taught me the importance of research. Going into any interaction whether an interview or an expert opinion, knowing the work and experience of the person on the other side is a demonstration of respect. Barry was critical to my passion and love for writing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learnt how to interview people. This course also made me think a lot - about fairness, biases, rules of journalism, what interviewees get out of being interviewed, what kinds of relationships you can have with your subjects etc. I really learnt a lot in this class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Yeoman guided us throughout the process of finding interviewee's, preparing for the interview, conducting it, analyzing your notes, doing follow-up, and writing the piece. Examples from his own work and the work of the guest speakers were really useful as I developed my own approach. I really liked the selection of readings and while I didn't resonate with every single one, it was nice to be able to come to class and hear what other people had to say about them that made me think of the writing/audio in a new way. I like the structure of a discussion-based class where I feel like everyone was comfortable to ask any questions at any point.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Yeoman explained to us how to go about finding current news stories we were interested in to then explore for our pieces throughout the semester - coming into the class, I was nervous I wouldn't find a topic I would be interested in doing 2 articles on, but quickly I learnt that shouldn't have been a worry. He also led us through every aspect of interviewing people, including the ethics, the actual dialogue, how to prepare, and so on. He also listened to our interviews and gave us personal advice for what to ask our interviewees next, as well as what specifically to work on. I would keep it all for future years.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor was very helpful and always able to provide feedback. He gave us helpful feedback on our assignments and was always very prompt in responding to emails. Thestructure of the Course, going from informative interviews to narrative interviews, helped build my journalism interviewing skills. Hearing from guest speakers who are journalists also helped me learn more, as did the long-form article readings. I would keep the assignments the way they are, I really liked getting actual feedback on my audio recording of interviews. I liked that we got to choose a social justice topic and really focus on it.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Barry was an incredible professor. I greatly enjoyed the structure of the assignments in which we had a semester-long topic but interviewed a multitude of different people, and I appreciated that the evaluation was largely on the interviewing piece, as that was what we had learned about in class. I also loved the readings and podcasts we did in preparation for the class sessions and thought that the class size was perfect for being able to thoroughly discuss and practice good interviewing and have ethical debates about journalistic practices.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Barry was extremely supportive and is clearly willing to put in as much effort and time as you need. The evaluation system allowed for a low-stress environment while also forcing you to do real work and accomplish significant things (like doing a series of intimate interviews with a stranger). I liked the structure of the course as well, with interviews of advocates coming before the narrative, personal interviews. It allowed me to get more comfortable with interviewing by speaking with people who didn't need as much guidance from the interviewer (me!).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This is point blank the best class I have taken in my Academic career and I am positive that all of my peers would agree. In the interviewing process for my longform journalism article, I learned how to TALK TO PEOPLE! I learned that just because I am younger I am not deserving of less respect and attention from adults. Huge. I learned how to buy into a draft a 15+ page article on a single story and how to be report. I learned the grammar of journalism and the rhythm of story telling. This class taught me so much more than academics -- it taught me that journalism is a way of life.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

response_text: I think Bronwen did an incredible job of balancing writing with reading in this course.
