question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Analyzing longform journalism pieces critically 
2. How to conduct interviews professionally and productively 
3. How to give constructive editing feedback to others

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Interview skills
- Scene building
- How to become a better journalist

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The most obvious skill you learn in this course is how to *do* longform journalism — how to write it, how to read it, how to understand it. In doing that, you learn how to ask good questions and follow-up with better ones, how to build source networks and get people to trust you. I came in with an extensive journalism background, having written longform before, and I learned more from this class than I have any other journalism class at Duke. Distilling it into a few things is a disservice to Barry.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to interview, write, and edit an article for long form journalism. I had no prior experience with long form writing before this, and I feel very comfortable with it now.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned how to write vivid and descriptive scenes, informative explainers, and how to structure one long-form journalism piece. I learned about the importance of writing with vivid detail and choosing every word carefully.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1: How to interview people who are vastly different from me with compassion and an eye for detail
2: How to write stories in a compelling and insightful way
3: How to research and work hard to ensure that I get all my facts straight and represent a truth in its fullest extent

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to report in long form style, writing journalism in a way that profiled characters, built scenes, and did every detail justice. I read so many wonderful examples of long form journalism that helped shape my style as a writer, interviewer, and reporter, and spent the semester working on a single piece that encapsulated months of reporting.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class taught me the process of crafting a long-form story with a donkey, or a main character to carry the narrative along, and themes that stem from specific details within the narrative to large themes of the world: power, justice, money. Every article we were assigned showcased a mastery of long form skills in different ways, exposing me to what it would be like to practice this type of writing as a career. I learned specifically about different long form structures, how to break down language, and efffective workshopping.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so much in this course. I have never taken a journalism class, and this has been easily my favorite class I have ever taken. I became a better reader, peer editor, and writer. I learned how to effectively interview, how to write scenes and explainers, and how to engage with topics of all variety. I learned how to interact with people and ideas different from my own.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I developed and strengthened a number of skills that made me a more effective communicator, both within the bounds of journalistic writing and on a broader scale. I improved my ability to deliver complex information in an accessible way, breaking down complicated topics so they could be more digestible to readers who may have little prior experience with the subjects I'm writing about. I worked on bringing in a human voice to the stories I tell, aiming to strike a better balance between explaining the histories and complexities of real-world issues and sharing the personal experiences of people connected to those issues. I also further developed my editing skills, honing my ability to provide thoughtful and helpful feedback to other students in my class -- not just on line edits for grammar/style, but also for larger structural elements like identifying gaps in the reporting and ways to make the overall narrative more engaging and compelling.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Improved my writing skills by learning new techniques in journalistic writing 
- Changed the way I read and engage with articles 
- Learned how to deal with and persevere through challenges in the reporting process

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I was a big fan of the dedicated smaller groups for workshopping. I think they worked really well to make sure people got good feedback while also keeping the class moving efficiently. I would definitely keep them for future years.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
- Guest speakers

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Barry is the best. Like seriously the best. He's compassionate and supportive but also holds high standards and works with you granularly. The structure of the course worked phenomenally well for me, with a series of small assignments, extensive revision periods, group workshops and intentional reading assignments, all of which made weekly workloads manageable but engaging and class time useful.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This was one of the best classes, if not the best class, I have taken at Duke. Prof. Yeoman was extremely helpful in creating a collaborative learning environment, and the 2.5 hour class always moved by super fast because of how it was split. I appreciated the workshop groups and working with peers, along with the guest speakers he invited.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The lectures were perfectly timed and engaging throughout, with breaks just when I needed them. The level of engagement with my peers was high, and allowed me to strengthen my ability to both communicate my critiques and take them in stride.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Barry created a comfortable, engaging community of writers. The class was small, and participation was a large part of the class, so I was always interested in material. We often had small group workshops where we received detailed feedback from peers on our writing, and passed around ideas regarding how we report and write. For every written assignment, Barry always offered extensive, helpful feedback. His attitude was overwhelmingly positive, while still always being constructive. I would not change the structure of the class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Yes, Barry is an incredible professor because he is engaging and can speak to his own experience in an informative and helpful way. The class, though 2.5 hours, was always broken down into learning about writing on a more general level, then discussing readings, then a lightning round of long form pieces each student enjoyed. Often there were other things tossed in the mix of class, like guest speakers or workshop periods, which also helped to make it more interesting! I'd keep this structure of teaching as it makes 2.5 hours fly by.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Barry is the best professor I have had at Duke. Barry truly cares about his students and wants us to succeed. Barry turns back assignments faster than any professor I have ever had, and his feedback is more extensive and helpful than any other professor. In class, Barry makes me want to speak and my thoughts feel valuable. The extensive feedback that Barry gives has made me a better writer. Also, the workshopping has been so helpful. Workshopping with our groups have taught me so much and helped me improve as an editor, peer, and writer. Also, the environment was fun! This class reminded me that I love learning and I love reading!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think Barry was an excellent instructor for a number of reasons, his approach to structuring the class included. I thought the workload was perfectly suited to the course, with enough required engagement with material to ensure that we were growing as readers and writers, but not so much that we were overwhelmed with the number of assignments before us. I enjoyed having one piece to work with each week that we could really dive into, and I liked having the response papers as a vehicle that prompted deeper reflection -- but not required every week to allow for some flexibility when our outside schedules got more intense. Same goes for the schedule of assignments related to the final paper -- I liked having smaller check-in excerpts due throughout the semester to keep us accountable to the reporting process, but appreciated being able to schedule interviews/reporting/writing on a timeline that worked for us up until the full draft was due near the end of the semester.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Yeoman was an incredible instructor -- I loved the structure of the course and how it matched with our progress on the semester-long project, allowing us to fully apply the material from class. He was also extremely helpful if I had questions or encountered difficulties.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: A lot of diversity in stories and material presented. The classes where we talked about the ethics of journalism in groups and practiced being an editor by writing creating our own magazines were extremely intellectually stimulating and fun!

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The weekly readings and discussions were fantastic because most of the time it was one piece that we delved into with great detail, so we could understand the writer and their motives. I also really liked the workshop groups because peer feedback was helpful. This was a class where Prof. Yeoman emphasized that grading isn't his priority, but he really rewards effort and the revision process.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It was fantastic because it presented this impossible and new task (creating a longform story) in bite sized ways that made it presentable and left me with a product that I'm super proud of.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: We met with multiple prolific journalists over the semester and frequently had large class discussions on our writing, reporting, and on difficult ethical questions in our journalism. question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: We read interesting writing. We learn about earthquakes, religion as power, whales, christian-rock festivals. Every class is different and exciting.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: We had great discussions!!! The lightning round at the end of each class encouraged me to engage with Longform journalism outside of class! Also, this course revived my love for reading, which has been dwindling. Remembering how much I love to read has made me very intellectually stimulated and has even helped me with my other classes.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It requires a lot of dedication and a willingness to work hard outside of class, but the insight and experience you gain is well worth it. Professor Yeoman is a fantastic teacher, and if you are willing to go to office hours he is always willing to help. I would highly recommend this course to anyone with even a passing interest in journalism or writing.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Do it. Even if you have no journalism background and no interest in journalism, you will learn so much about how to be a better writer and interviewer, and will do so in a class community and with a professor that wants nothing more than to help you thrive.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a phenomenal course that I would highly recommend for both those interested in journalism and people just interested in writing. I have improved my writing significantly in this course and you will too!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Barry truly is a teacher like no other. I would highly recommend attending his office hours. The course is fantastic on its own, but it is truly transformative with the individual help from office hours. Regardless, this is probably my favorite class I have ever taken in my life.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would tell a future student to manage their time well. I would also tell them to just read any long form journalism they can, and to participate in class. If they do the required work, then they have nothing to worry about. The 2.5 hour classes don't feel long at all.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about the world of journalism and the current issues the industry faces with trust and retaining ethical standards of content that reflect well on journalism as a whole. I also learned about different mediums of journalism and how to write better papers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: On the first day of this course, Professor Adair anonymously asked us how much news we consume on a given day... I was one of the students who consumed 0 articles/day and now I consume 5+ articles/day... all because of this class! Even though the class can be "depressing," as it explores the topic of lack of trust in journalism, it actually made me enjoy reading the news for the first time ever. Instead of reading a news article and only thinking about the subject matter of the article, I now think about how the article fits with the news outlet's business goals (ex: Athletic articles in NYT), whether it is "solutions journalism," whether it could contribute to the problem of "news avoidance," etc.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Entering this class I had no experience in journalism and was apprehensive of my ability to interact and engage. However, this class was an incredible introduction and inspiration to journalism. The flow of the class from the structures of journalism to innovative solutions was logical to follow. First, I gained knowledge about journalism ethics, the different types of reporting, and interviewing jargon that I will take with me into my professional career. However, these barely covered the surface of the deep insights I gained into the implications of partisan media and the challenges all media companies face. The discussions of Fox compared to CNN and MSNBC were eye-opening and going deeper into more unique media sources allowed me to interact with formats I had not seen before.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:

I developed an understanding of the issues facing journalism.
I learned about the different forms of journalism, both traditional and non-traditional.

response_text:

I have learned how to apply these skills in different formats of media.

response_text: I developed a deeper understanding of the foundations of journalism and journalistic principles, the necessary role fact-checking plays in journalism as well as in our larger democracy, and the evolution of the journalism industry as well as the threats it currently faces.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think that it was pretty stimulating as it is, but I think at times debates felt a little one-sided or simple. Maybe in order to combat this, more of the readings could be from conservative outlets or perhaps "extra credit" of not only keeping up with Reliable Sources/The Morning but also regularly consuming news from right-leaning papers. Not sure how feasible that is but an idea.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

Also, they're fun. And if the stakes are relatively low, I think it would be beneficial.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how important it is to report against your beliefs and stay quick on your feet in this industry. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class was amazing. I learned countless things throughout the semester, so I'll just name a few. First, I learned that objectivity is a difficult ideal to achieve in journalism, and the closest we can get to total objectivity is by reporting against our own biases and hypotheses. I also learned that there is no single path to a successful career in journalism, and many successful reporters began their professional lives in other careers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. The intersection between journalism and community-building. 
2. How the news functions as a first draft of history which is why journalistic practices of fairness and truth-seeking are so important. 
3. Ways journalism can distinguish itself in an increasingly crowded media environment.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: lots of insights from acclaimed guest speakers in the journalism field, knowledge about the troubles facing the news industry today, knowledge about the values and principles that journalism ought to embody

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I learned how to make my writing more muscular, the importance of collecting trustworthy sources, and the type of commitment that it really takes to be a journalist.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

response_text: This was the best course I have ever taken at Duke. I learned how to read interresting articles, analyze news sources for credibility, and have intellectually engaging discussions about them.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: evaluating the news more analytically, historical precedent about the news, journalism specifics from the different speakers

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think above all this course taught me the importance of thinking holistically due to the fact that it gave me a greater appreciation for the process of journalism. 2 other things I learned include the importance of being articulate and up-to-date on current affairs as well as the importance of listening and trying to understand opposing viewpoints to the greatest of extents. Without opposing viewpoints, we wouldn't have journalism.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I've learned about the structures of newspapers - how they are divided and structured. 
I have learned about what good journalism is about - having courage, curiosity, and conviction when pursuing the truth.
I've learned about the different types of journalism, from objective news reporting to morning bulletins and opinion editorials, and how journalism can shape history.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to think critically about journalism and journalistic issues; how to research and form evidence-supported opinions; the values of journalism

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Many of the topics we explored in this course are subjects I engage with daily in my role as news editor of The Chronicle. However, I enjoyed being able to hear the varying perspectives of my peers -- many of whom do not have extensive journalism backgrounds -- on some of the ethical questions I am consistently grappling with. The subjects we discussed included how news agendas are determined and why it's important to balance the slate of coverage on a given day, the importance of anonymous sources and dangers associated with using them too frequently, the obligation to thoroughly fact-check all reporting, and much more.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how journalists think in regards to how they write, develop and produce news. One thing that I learned that stands out is that "facts are expensive, opinions are cheap." Being sure to take the time to research is important especially when crafting stories. I also learned the importance of clarity when writing and when reporting. And the importance of follow up questions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about the principles, economics and different mediums of journalism and how those coincide in a digital world that is constantly evolving.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
The Role of Journalism in Society - What function does the news play? How has it shaped history? How do people interact with it? How has it changed?
Interdisciplinary thinking - How to approach complex challenges relating to justice and morality in a world constrained by business and personal influence 
Writing - How to edit our writing to ensure we make every word count and aren't redundant

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course helped a lot with my writing. Professor Tash took the time to read my paper, mark it up, and offer in-depth feedback.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This was my first journalism class, and I learned a ton about what the field is actually like, the types of stories produced, and how much variety there is in terms of long-form writing, TV broadcasting, podcasts, etc. This class also helped me work on my own writing skills through feedback on my essays, to just getting to read a vast collection of work over the semester and learn from those authors.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to write in a less academic/more journalistic way, critically ask questions, and critically approach news.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I had know and understood the threats that journalism faces, but I learned more about the complexity and evolution of these threats. It is an insight that I will carry with me as I consume media coverage for the rest of my life. In addition to refining my media literacy skills, I developed news ways of thinking when it comes to understanding the journalism industry. It is not just newspapers and TV outlets, but a blooming industry full of startups and people who simply want to share stories that are interesting to them.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course did an excellent job of pushing students to think with perspective. As the semester continued on, I realized that in class discussion there was no right answer for anything we were discussing. Debating the moral ethics of journalism is no easy feat, and this class kept me engaged with the world around me, improving not just practical skills like my writing, but also helped me become more of a global citizen.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Incredible insight into the journalism world and profession, both through Professor Tash's experience and the amazing speakers
- Writing development: I have never had a professor take so much time and attention in helping us write better. 
- Hearing opinions and experiences differing from mine in respectful and productive ways

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot through the course of the semester. In fact, as my first and only journalism class of college, I feel grateful it was this one. I learned to think of news as a moral battleground, and received a well-lit tour of the horizon. I learned about partisanship in the news media and to be conscious of framing. I also learned about several important stories on an international, national and local level. Most importantly, I learned about what good journalism and writing looks like, and some tips and tricks to get there.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to analyze news academically, journalism ethics and morals, ways in which to help the journalism industry in the future

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Synthesizing readings, research and writing skills, creative and critical thinking

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to be a conscious consumer of the news, how to develop my journalistic writing skills, and how to analyze different news articles.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a tremendous amount about the anatomy of the news business from national to local scales, the shortcomings and bright spots of the industry, and what strong, proper journalism should look like. The guest speakers were phenomenal, shedding light on some of the most pivotal moments in the history of journalism and the impact they have on our world. It was especially interesting to hear these guest speakers speak about the actual process of launching an investigation or expose of a particular subject. This class puts into perspective the indispensable role journalism plays in our society, and that we as a citizenry have an obligation to do our part to preserve that.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: As a STEM major / not having a pub pol or journalism background, this class was super interesting! I learned about the complexities and challenges surrounding both news reporting and journalistic consumption. My favorite aspects dealt with the discussions surrounding the evolution of the news -- how topics such as fact-checking, polarization, and bias have changed drastically in the last decade and especially the last few years. The class was focused on present-day trends not history which I liked.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

response_text: Professor Tash is a master of this craft, and I could not be more grateful to learn from someone not only as experienced but also as compassionate as him. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Tash created a robust environment for learning with the facilitated conversations. Most of the time, class was split into halves, one for a guest speaker, and one for discussion. In these discussion everyone came prepared, ready to discuss the materials assigned. This definitely contributed to the liveliness of the classroom, but it was Tash who kept us engaged with stories, asking us to dig deeper in our responses, and carefully choosing what material to assign to us.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: 1. journalism structuring 2. how to receive feedback 3. how to work on a long term piece

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to be a better journalist who can structure, write and edit longer articles. I also learned how to be a valuable member of a team, constantly providing my peers with feedback for their articles. I also developed time management skills as I finished a long piece throughout the course of an entire semester.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: interviewing, writing, scene building, communication, collaboration, editing, etc

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
This class taught me a lot about building scenes, particularly for journalism writing (but also writing in general). I learned a lot of practical advice that helped me in other courses that involved writing.
I became an avid reader of long-form journalism because of this course; it introduced me to websites like Sunday Long Read and Longform.org, and I'm very grateful for that.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to interview respectfully, how to approach a monumental writing task in small pieces, how to empathize with stories different from our own

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I improved my writing, research skills, and interview techniques. I also improved in overall communication.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. We learned how to write a scene. We learned about the technical aspects including information to include but also artistic aspects about how to best recreate a point in time. 
2. We learned about different structures of long form journalism. We learned how to weave information between scenes to create a full picture of an issue and its underlying events. 
3. We read many long form articles and discusses how the authors' choices contributed to the emotional impact, clarity, and flow.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: My writing was improved, specifically my scene writing and my comfort using the first-person when necessary. I learned a whole lot about how to find details where they may not be obvious, how to look for specificities and how to represent them well in journalistic writing. Most importantly, I learned how to apply radical empathy to the job of journalist.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class was a stellar deep dive into skills I thought I had already acquired. This is a class for beginner writers of many kinds, but especially the writer who has never dealt with creative ways of expressing ideas. I learned so much about how to write beautifully, how to tell someone's story in a way that does them justice, and how to phrase ideas in unique ways. On top of beautiful writing skills, I learned a lot about how to critique and take criticism. Barry effectively sets an example for how to break down works, both iconic and beginner pieces, and understand their structure, their qualities, and potential improvements. Additionally, we learned how to investigate. I believe this is applicative to many classes. Research is a term broadly used in descriptions for investigative pieces, but Barry emphasizes that research comes in many forms. I loved this class and I can confidently say I have learned the most in this once-a-week seminar compared to any other class at Duke.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this class, I really did learn how to write a long form article. We read new stories and analyzed them every week and were given the opportunity to craft our own over the semester. I was introduced to new writers, ways of writing, and ideas.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: he did a great job including checks and balances all throughout the semester so that we had feedback on our writing throughout the entire process.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: He relied a lot on peer feedback sessions and divided the class into small groups. We had the same workshop group for the entire semester, and it really helped us develop lasting relationships and approach peer editing in a more intimate and comprehensive way.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Barry Yeoman was the best professor I've ever had Duke. Our class and I absolutely adored him in every way. He instilled confidence in all of us. He believed in us. He granted us tips and tricks while also giving us the time to build. I have never learned more in a class and have been more eager to apply my learnings to my future. Barry grew a community of friendship in this class and I looked forward to it every week.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Yeoman has been one of my favorite teachers I have had so far at Duke. He is so personable and approachable, and he makes every single class engaging (it doesn't feel 2.5 hours long). I like the way the semester is structured in three parts.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Barry was phenomenal. He came with a plan, mapping out class to the minute, but it never felt constricted. It actually allowed for some breathing and flexibility. His comments always allowed our class to bounce off one another and make it truly feel like a round table seminar of sorts. By splitting up the gigantic task of a long-form piece into all of his components, it truly revealed his paramount writing skills and, more importantly, his masterful teaching.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Writing a long form article for the first time is daunting, but the structure of this class and Barry Yeoman's constant encouragement and suggestions made it enjoyable. Over the course of the semester, we wrote one major long form article, but it was split up in parts. I really enjoyed this way of writing. We also had workshop groups that facilitated conversation and helped with edits. All of the feedback I got was so helpful and I feel as though I am a better writer after this semester.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) I learned how to articulate the causes of the local news problem and how to describe the current circumstances and consequences of the local news problem.
2) I gained insight into how the current culture and environment of the journalism landscape incentivizes some journalists to plagiarize or fabricate facts in their stories, like Stephen Glass.
3) I'm now able to better emphasize in what way the journalist of an article is biased—and I can also avow that all journalists and people are biased in some way. For example, you can be biased towards the truth.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this class, I learned how to think critically about the partisan divide in news and reframe my perspective. I learned how to read articles from opposing viewpoints with an open mind, and consider the bias in journalism. As someone who tries to  naively and impossibly avoid politics, I was also pushed out of my comfort zone to analyze partisan issues and consider the polarization of our news. Go narrow and deep.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I found that the course struck a perfect balance between class speakers and lecturing from Bill. And throughout both mediums, we were continuously empowered as students to ask questions and contribute to the discussion. Specifically, I think the class speakers are what helped to facilitate student learning. Not only did we hear from journalists and journalist experts, but we also heard from students like us who have ventured into journalism and encountered its problems from a fresh perspective. We heard from right-wing-leaning media owners. We heard from people who were impacted by right-wing media rabbit holes firsthand. Essentially, we got a variety of perspectives on the state of journalism, and this empowered us to use these testimonies to form our own conclusions.I also think all of the writing assignments clearly signaled relevance to the class, and they helped to apply and facilitate our learning. The individual prompts were also well-timed with what we were currently learning about or where we were in the course syllabus/timeline.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was undoubtedly stimulating. The variety of guest speakers with different backgrounds and political leanings combined with the immersive lectures gave us a broad and enriched perspective on the ethical problems of journalism. Most lectures were audiovisual in nature, and the readings and writing assignments we were assigned pertained directly to how we as students consume media and the behind-the-scenes of the media we consume. Finally, we were continuously encouraged to ask and answer questions, which made the class interactive.

response_text: This class can be difficult and at some times depressing. Journalism largely contributes to the divide in our country, and try to fix it can be a bit of a downer. You'll be challenged to reframe your thinking in many ways and consider tough topics.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about the influence that journalism plays in supporting and contributing to democracy within the United States. Specifically, I learned about the evolution of the news environment, how policy and journalism influence one another, and explored significant historical moments of journalism reporting.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about the relationship between the press and the government, as well as about the changes journalism has faced in the last 50 or so years. I was able to develop analytical skills to evaluate the practices of journalists and the media and how we can better improve to serve our democracy.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Presentation skills, knowledge of US history, defense of one's ideas of beliefs.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained skills in writing analytical academic essays. I feel I am a better consumer of news and have more insight into the relationship between press and government.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned new ways of thinking about the relationship between the press and the government through the readings and activities in this course. I gained knowledge of the history of the watergate scandal, the rise of right wing media, and generally the forces that have brought to bear our current media environment.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) So much subject-specific knowledge, including the norms of journalism, the American press system and its relationship with the government, and, most importantly, what the evolution of the American media ecosystem would mean for both national & global democracy — this prompted a LOT of reflection regarding what my role as a citizen as well as an aspiring journalist is.
2) I learned to think and write like a journalist (Dr. Sullivan especially, being a pro-journalist, imparted so much wisdom to us) — I learned about effective, clear, and engaging information delivery, and how to critically analyze sources for relevancy.
3) A specific 'piece' of knowledge that was super thought-provoking for me was the existence of the press as business entities as well, and how much attracting audiences and generating profits that way influenced the inner workings of the press. Applying that to real life was even more eye-opening — the paywalls blocking access to the New York Times and the Washington Post, for example, are an example of business models that work... But is this at the cost of information access (leading to a more informed populace)? This class really helped me ponder questions like this.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
1) I really liked how discussion-oriented our class was — we were provided with a guiding question each lesson, and it was so interesting exploring various facets of the topic and then delving into further 'branches' of discussion based on interesting observations and points of analysis that my classmates made.
2) Our guest speakers were amazing, and I learned so much from listening to them and asking them questions. Len Downie, who was a key figure in the Washington Post's reporting surrounding the Watergate Scandal, for example, spoke to us, and it was so eye-opening hearing about his first-hand experience — it really brought what we learned to life! (IT'D BE SO COOL TO KEEP BRINGING IN AWESOME GUEST SPEAKERS — EXPERTS IN THE JOURNALISM FIELD — FOR FUTURE STUDENTS & FUTURE CLASSES!)
3) By extension, the syllabus was also super clear — readings for each class (accompanied by our guiding discussion question) were laid out since the beginning of the semester, as were our deadlines. This helped me prepare for our class discussions and helped me contextualize the readings and identify key points.
4) I also liked how the class only happened once a week (but for a long time — 2 hours & 30 minutes) — this meant that the class was more low-stress & manageable, which helped with my learning since I had more time to properly digest the material we'd discuss.
5) Our instructors also created an awesome learning environment — they were super casual, which made me feel a lot more comfortable and confident expressing my views!

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text:
1) How deeply it encouraged us to think about the structural issues underpinning the American media ecosystem, its role in upholding democracy, and its ramifications (e.g., tribalization & polarization). Before coming to Duke, I was aware that polarization was a huge issue, but this class provided so much context as to why this was the case.
2) This class made me think about how to be a better journalist (in practice) and brought issues and debates at the forefront of the journalism industry right into our classroom.
3) The course content also helped me consider my own experience with democracy and journalism in my home country, where democracy is eroding — I loved how applicable the course content was!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked Coates' teaching style - some film clips, some discussion, some lecture. I really liked how we had four in-class film screening days - we watched "The Conjuring," "Star Wars," "God's Not Dead," and "Kumaré." I liked our "mini review" assignments, where you basically produce a 7-minute film review using a class reading from that specific unit and you have to argue why it should be considered religious. The movies and clips we'd watch in class were more obviously religious, so this was a chance for us to get creative and find something that seems secular and apply it to our learnings.
